description:
We were a party of 20 and the worker was very accommodating. He had Great service and everything was made  Fresh. Food was delicious. The "all you can eat" is very affordable. Less than $7 a person. 


The pork bun is my favorite. Soft on the outside and very flavorful in the inside.

Will definitely Be returning.
author: G Y.

description:
From the looks out of the outside sign, when you see $6.39 (which is $7.00 with tax), for all you can eat Dim Sum, it sounds like an amazing deal! And if you had all the time in the world, it probably would be financially a good deal, just not a very delicious one.

The reason for that is that it takes them forever to bring out food. I guess they make it fresh, which is nice and cool, but so you do need to realize that when you are initially ordering food, you should probably order everything you want, because by the time the second round comes you've had already stayed there so long that you just to leave.

Even though the food was "freshly" prepared, it wasn't all that good and left a lot to be desired. The cleanliness is a bit questionable in my eyes too, some of the sauce dishes looked quite a bit dirty.

Overall, if you just want to save money and have all the time in the world, sure this place fits the bill. But there are so many places in San Francisco that you can enjoy a much nicer meal and not feel shitty afterwards.
author: Tyler T.

description:
Be careful with your credit card bill. You can pay by credit card here on the boss' cell phone. He took it back so quickly that I might not be able to click the "confirm" bottom. Anyway, the total amount charged shows that I paid 25% tips. How come??? BTW, the dim sum was below average.
小心信用卡盗刷，莫名其妙被收了25%的小费。估计是我还没点下确定，就被老板抢走了刷卡的手机，然后老板自己选的。另外点心质量很差，我东部村里都没这么差的点心。别去！
author: Chengxi L.

description: Got 3 items. $1 for 2 fried meat buns, $6.50 wonton soup, $4.99 peanut butter rice noodles. First, fried meat buns were cheap, tasted average, though it was fried, the bun was smushy.  Wonton soup, like come on, 5 wontons? I had to use the spoon to keep scooping up wontons to see if I miscounted, it was 5, in a pool of liquid, which the liquid tasted like water, Msg, salt, white pepper powder and dish soap. Felt scammed. Lastly, I got to say, the rice noodles texture was good. The boss said that it was handmade, but I wouldn't order it again, nothing special. Total of $13.5 charged for this meal, could eat better elsewhere. The boss, and the lady there was really friendly though, just the food is lacking in quality and taste.
author: Blank C.

description: First time going to San Francisco's Chinatown and what caught my attention was the AYCE dim sum!!! It was like $6.50 for lunch and $7.99 for dinner. There's no such thing as AYCE dim sum in Chicago so I was elated to go and try the food out. The food was okay but the owner was nice and attentive. I came to explore but I would recommend getting other food besides Shiu mai or the beef shiu mai.
author: Will T.

description: Great old fashioned type of Chinese food place. Restaurant is ran by an older husband and wife. No one else. The man upfront is the owner and server and is extremely friendly and encourages you to eat all you can and don't stop. Don't let the appearance and paper plates fool you. This place is awesome. Will come back all the way from the east bay.
author: Al M.

description:
Pros: 5 for $1 BBQ pork buns, price is great! You can't beat $.20 for some small steamed Baos. Charge $.10 extra for the tax , so technically $1.10 total.

Cons: all orders are made fresh to order so it took over 25+ minutes for 5 small Bao's which I asked for to go. We ended up having to sit down inside of the restaurant to wait, not like other places where you can take it to go immediately. The BBQ pork buns are mostly bread (bread is also kind of dry, slightly more crumbly than I like it) , they're not incredibly flavorful (I found the pork sort of bland). Unfortunately it seems like it's a one man show being run at this place, which is why service is a bit slow. Just didn't feel like it was worth it in the end to wait that long but guess it's pretty decent value for your money if you're not too picky about the buns themselves...
author: Kristie M.

description:
All you can eat dim sum for 5.99! My general knowledge to what dim sum is that it's generally filled with pork-- which is what my partner and I don't like. So we made this face with our tongue out and kept walking up the block. We were looking for pastries to bring home and we saw a stand in front of Dick Lee's. We didn't realize it was a part of the same company and we're lured by the wrapped sweet rice and taro buns. I tried to explain to my foreign partner what the pastries were and the owner seemed nice. 

We were sat down, charged an extra 50cents when we weren't asked if we wanted it for a dine-in or to-go. The wrapped rice came with honey and sugar. My mom used to make these so I was a bit excited. My partner didn't like it and it was a bit on the super plain side. I don't know how to exactly describe it but it was fairly burned and needed a lot of sugar. We sadly ate it and finished what we could to show some respect that we had food on our plate.

Taro buns were better than the wrapped sweet rice by miles. I can't compare it to any other bakeries in town because we lost our appetite and fell short on money. The food was pretty expensive for one item each, I wonder if we should've opted for the 5.99 ayce. Owner and service was nice at least.. 

I recommend giving this place your own try, but if you're looking to spend your money for something cheap and worth it... continue to walk up the hill to another bakery to get your money's worth.
author: Liza H.

description:
1. The owner/server was incredibly informative and attentive! He notified us when things were not on the "all you can eat" and made sure we were okay with the price difference. Also a party of three with vegetarians came and he made SURE he separated the meat and vegetarian options. 

2. Food was good! The buns were stuffed with meat. The food was HOT and fresh tasting. The egg rolls could burn so be careful. I loved everything we ordered besides the rice. Only complaint is the rice was a bit mushy. 

3. The bill was exact. Curious considering other yelpers "experiences" 

4. I will come back!!!
author: Shannen T.

description:
AVOID AVOID The man at the front charged us ( 3 people)  $37 for dim sum and we waited 49 minutes still no food!!!  When we told him we were leaving he wouldn't give us a refund so we waited. 

We finally got a piece of dim sum- disgusting, I spit it out. I have never tasted worst food- what was this! We called the police after two other parties left- one person threw a plate at the owner. We waited so long for the worst food. 

I called the police because after spitting out the food no refund and the other customers were all yelling as well. This place is a crock.... 

TIP: DO NOT GO - THE FOOD HAS A WIERD TASTE SOMEONE SHOULD CALL THE HEALTH DEPARTMENT- SOMETHING IS WRING WITH THE FOOD- NO REFUNDS BECAUSE THEY KNOW HOW BAD IT IS 5.99 all you can eat dim sum!!!! Do not go here ever.  Turn away!
author: Sara F.

description: When driving down Jackson Street, my friend spotted the $6.39 ALL YOU CAN EAT LUNCH and we knew we had to send it! Now this isn't any ordinary Chinese joint this is the BEST CHINESE JOINT. When walking into Dick Lee's some might say the decor is "dated", but they're wrong! This place is a portals into modern day China. Once stepping into the place, you immediately be greeted by the one, the only, Dick Lee himself! Now I experience something I had never experienced before here. Mr. Lee turned customers away because the place was to busy. After being seated you'll take a glance at the menu and notice the one of a kind menu. It's a very self explanatory menu. You'll write your order on a folded up piece of paper and hand it to Dick Lee. Most people think that the food takes to long but they're not taking advantage of the time. You have to fully take in the decor. My favorite piece is the windows computer from cave men times! It's like a cherry on top! The food doesn't come all at once it comes in no particular order or course. It keeps you on your toes and guessing on what's coming out next. Now the quality of the food is up for debate. Some people seemed to be disappointed in the food, but I couldn't disagree more. The food was something from out of this world. I've never tasted anything like it before it certainly is a unique spot!
author: Buddy P.

description:
Some people said their foods were slow but freshly made - have you ever tasted freshly made dim sum? or have you not experienced with FROZEN dimsum? Or are you blind and not see the cardbox next to the trash can saying FROZEN DIM SUM-.- 

The owner said all dim sum were steamed for 15 min so it would taste better. Ok, let's talk about the quality then. 
Beef or Pork Sui mai - Dry, hard, smell like dead mouse
Seafood dumpling - I don't see or taste any seafood beside it looks like a fish kind of shape. Taste spicy and old.
Shark's Fin dumpling - It is litterally the same as pork siu mai.

No water for you, or you can purchase some???!

Take your dish/left over and dump into trash can yourself??? And you want us to tips???

As a native Chinese, I know for sure what good dim sum taste like. This place is just a very nasty, fake, and shitty place. 

Like the other said, if you are broke and hungry, come here and fill up your stomach and feel shitty afterward. Cuz it is just cheap. I mean, don't expect anything from cheap place, especially you are in chinatown!
author: Kalum Z.

description: I love this little spot. I come here whenever I'm in Chinatown. It's pretty low-key, no frills, but the food and the owner is worth it. Always get the All You Can Eat Dim Sum and I never leave disappointed.
author: Maria Katherine S.

description: First time to San Francisco, so we decided to make a stop to Frisco's famous "China Town". As we searched for a light lunch, we came across a sign that read, "All you can eat dim sum $5.99", and my sister was quickly enticed. We had all been craving dim sum, so this little hole in the wall shop would be our quick fix. We ordered 1 order of Siu Mai, 1 order of Steamed Won Tons, & also received 1 order of Steamed Pork Buns (complimentary of Yelp for checking-in). The food was mediocre at best, but the service was very good. If it wasn't for the nice service, I'd have given this spot a 1 star review. You can definitely get better dim sum elsewhere, but if you're on a budget and just need a quick fix to eat: you can't beat all you can eat for $5.99.
author: Ashley V.

description: Their stereo broadcast of "all you can eat" is obnoxious. Their food is terrible. Their prices are low. But I wouldn't go.
author: Betty L.

description: This place is my favorite place.  I love taro bun. Its so delicious and not expensive. I love this place
author: Warisara S.

description: Oh, I can use only bad words for this place , but in future can be scale of bad food.if you want to be good poison come to this place. But there is one good thing about this place , the waiter is very friendly.
author: Orod B.

description:
The worst food and customer services experience！！！Food sucks，do not come to this place，this place is a trap of tourists ！The owner is not nice to the customers，he charges us more money ，when I ask  why charge me  more ，he said that is the tax！！！What is that high percentage tax！！！
then ，he demands every customers to sit down and wait，I am so mad at his bad attitude ，do not come this place ，do not！！！
author: Mia L.

description: A small, no frills Chinese all you can eat place. 7.99$ for all you can eat. For the price, it's a miracle. Only 2 people (husband and wife) run the show. You have to be patient. Everything you order comes fresh. The man keeps asking you to eat more. It's delightful to watch him at work. Taste is good too.
author: SatyaPrakash P.

description: Bummer food wasn't better. Dim sum steamed buns were all 95% bread and no filler. Some of the steamed dumplings had little flavor or weird tasting filler. Everything was really greasy and heavy. The egg rolls were the only thing that was good. Atmosphere was run down but owner was very friendly.
author: Ken R.

description:
Let me start off by saying that you could probably find better food anywhere else except Berkeley's dining halls. But the fact that they serve edible ayce dim sum for $6 is a steal. It's really a 3 star place but I added an additional star because I didn't get food poisoning.

The food itself is meh. It's a bit below average but Its certainly not awful or inedible. Their selection isn't extensive but includes dessert and the usual suspects. If you're broke and starving, this place might be worth checking out.
author: Mike K.

description: Worst experience I've ever had at a dim sum place. Rude owner. He lied about the food being ready to grab and go. He over charged me and the food was terrible. If you're looking for poor quality food with an even poorer level of service, this the place for you.
author: C S.

description: What are these other helpers even talking about??? This place is Amazing! We were on a 7 bar pub crawl in Chinatown and after hitting our 5th bar, we needed food! Nothing was open and I mean nothing except the dick Lee pastry shop. The proprietor was great and accommodating ! He was gracious to 5 drunks and served us a delicious round of BBQ buns, egg rolls and fried rice! Yelpers of San Francisco learn to love your local treasures !
author: La S.

description: Food was average for a 5.99 all you can eat. The owner was entertaining. Always funny.
author: Miriam T.

description:
One would think that a place like this would draw people in by the crowds since Dim Sum typically is about $2.50 for a serving of 3 pieces at any to go place. This place was listing themselves for less than 4 orders at a sit-down location. While open they even tried to sell some of the food to go.

This place had been closed for months. Just recently reopened their to-go area for the Chinese New Years stuff. Once that was over, they were closed once more.
author: M C.

description: If you looking for great Chinese dum sim go no further 5.99 all you can eat swear best Chinese food yet.
author: Ed M.

description:
The owner takes money from u,  orders u to sit down without giving u your change of $15 from a $5 food order, turns around and starts new transactions with other customers, and involves in kitchen chores. Remember u demand for your change loud & clear. 

Heard other customer asked for a receipt. The owner replied your email would be email to u.
The customer said But I didn't give u my email address???
Never heard e-mail address involved in a fast food place like this. 

The owner's colleague yelled loud from pain suddenly there's gotta be a step on her foot by the owner or some kind of kitchen accident. He just stared at her. No apology. No caring words. 

Speed of the food came ok. But wonton expired tasted bad. I didn't bother to tell him. Ate all the noodles left the rotten wontons. 

I guess he wasn't a bad guy. He almost looks a little adorable. I guess he is only a little mentally ill cos he wants to be in Hollywood. But he has to be in San Francisco chinatown everyday. 

Elvis Presley & Michael Jackson save his business cos that's all he plays, funky & cool. No dim um place plays Elvis & MJ exclusively, which attracts silly tourists to go in. 

Tons of memory notes from customers on his walls saying how wonderful the place was. You know, like a hostel. 

I suggest him to open a hostel in Hollywood for a more ideal life for himself. Don't get the mental health locked up by a business. Lots of folks are in his shoes I bet, he's not alone. 

I however walked out feeling very disoriented.
author: Fong Yu K.

description:
I asked the front man how much of the all you can eat was vegetarian. I was worried our language barrier would make an answer impossible. I said no meat and no egg. I wasn't sure it was understood.

Fortunately it was understood! Unfortunately, it was just ok food. 

He brought fried rice with no egg. It was just salted, burned rice with corn, cabbage, and carrots. 
He was also helpful in directing me to the fried spring rolls, lotus bun, and taro bun. He also brought mushroom dumplings when I asked. 

The problem is the food just wasnt that great. I understand my vegetarian options were extremely limited. Meat eaters might find more. One extra star for his service! $5.99 is an ok value.
author: ShmoHaw K.

description: Great iced coffee. Best AYCE dim sum on earth. The food was huge! Will eat here again.
author: Misty K.

description:
These other yelp reviews are so dramatic, they seem fake. (Like many review sites, some people are paid to make positive or negative reviews)

My experience here was great. Very affordable and delicious dim sum. All of my portions were very hot and had great composition. The smaller pork buns were really nice too, great filling to bun ratio. I really dislike having too much bun. The dessert buns (birthday bun was my fav) were excellent! They went well with some hot soy milk. Don't expect fast service when it's busy, take your time and be friendly, it's a mom and pop shop. They'll make your food as you order it so it might take a while. The menu is limited, but what they make is great and after a couple orders and some fried rice, you'll be full.

I'd go again!
author: Garrett M.

description:
I was craving for dim sum, so I decided to go to Chinatown to scout for some delicious dim sum. I chose to eat at this place because I was hungry and the $5.99 all you can eat dim sum sign definitely caught my attention. I didn't expect much from this place because of how cheap the food is. However, the dim sum was very delicious and the owner offered great service. 

My favorites were the fried rice, shu mai, birthday bun, BBQ pork bun, taro bun, and fresh soy milk. The food may not taste like top quality food from an upscale dim sum restaurant, but the food definitely reminded me of a good home cooked meal. 

A few things you should know before setting your expectations of this place:
1. This is a very small mom and pop restaurant, which means it is only operated by two people. The wife is usually in the back cooking, while the husband is the only one serving customers.

2. They make everything fresh, so you would have to wait for your food. 

3. The buns you're gonna get from here is a lot smaller compared to other places. However, I like it very much because the buns are hot, tasty, and very easy to eat even if you're getting full. They are delicious miniature buns with perfect amount of fillings.  

4. If you're getting All You Can Eat Dim Sum, don't be afraid to tell the owner what you need. He will be busy because he's the only one tending to customers so bare with him. He's very accommodating and friendly. 

5. There isn't a wide variety of dim sum to choose from, but the food will still be enough to fill you!

Yes, I recommend this place.
author: Shelly L.

description: Food was good. Service was with a smile. I you can eat left me full. Would come again if I lived in the area.
author: vetella s.

description: The ambience is amazing! Little hole in the wall in Chinatown. If you're walking through and looking for affordable dim sum this is the place to stop. The chef was so welcoming and happy. It made our day! All you can eat for $5.99 and great food! Don't forget to leave paper note review!
author: Jonathan L.

description:
It honestly shocks me that food can be THIS bad. Honestly, I was just appalled by the quality of the food because it takes actual effort to put food out to customers that is this horrible.

My friend and I ordered the unlimited dim sum. After waiting for a very long time, I asked the man working if it was almost done. He said it would be out shortly, called our number, and then handed us two plates of food that we didn't order. It was some sort of chicken wings and scattered fries. I didn't touch it...my friend ate one fry and it was cold. Looked like someone's leftovers? It was just bizarre, especially since we didn't even ask for it.

Moments later, he told us to go to the steamers to grab the dim sum. Absolutely NOTHING looked like it did in the photos that were shown on the menu. The "shrimp dumplings" were literally not even shrimp so I refused to eat them. The sui mai was probably the only half decent thing there, and it just tasted like an oily meaty mess. I was honestly terrified that I was eating questionable meat. 

Please don't come here. PLEASE. Not worth it at ALL! You can find food so much better for $6.
author: Mars S.

description: The man is very nice I really like him. Also the food is pretty good and fast service!
author: Anthony S.

description:
We walked by and had heard about the all you can eat dim sum for cheap.  Less than $6 for dim sum? Crazy! There were signs advertising various deals and we decided, what the heck, let's try the milk tea and some custard buns for $5.  We went inside to wait for our order and found a few tables occupied that were set up like picnic tables.

We saw customers walk up to the area where they could choose from various dumplings and maybe steamed buns? I couldn't see all the items to choose from but it didn't look like more than 5 items in the steamers.  There's a washroom but when I asked for the key, I was told someone was in there by I'm assuming Dick.  But then a minute later another person in our group was given a key.  I didn't use the washroom so I can't comment but was told it's not a toilet to sit on! 

We waited about 5 minutes and the milk tea and buns were ready.  The buns weren't eaten right away and by the time we got back to the hotel, they were hard as rock.  After microwaving, they tasted ok.  Will not be back here and the all you can eat dim sum doesn't look appealing at all.
author: Violet P.

description:
$6 AYCE dim sum = :) 

Surprised by the horrible reviews of this place. I personally didn't mind the experience - sure it wasn't the best customer service but what do you expect from Chinatown? My friends and I thought the experience was unique and the food wasn't all that bad. We left satisfied and full.
author: Priscilla T.

description: First of all, the insanely awesome low price is great. Then you get the food which taste amazing!! Home made stuff! But the absolute best part of our dinner here was our server uncle Peter! This man is such a delight to interact with. He's very bubbly and airways happy and generous! Amazing person that I wish more people in the service industry would be like! Thank you Uncle Peter for your excellent service and delicious Chinese food!!
author: Andrew C.

description:
I was torn between a 2 and a 3. My friend, her daughter (my Goddaughter), and I went for the all you can eat dim sum. Some was good, some was not so good....and there were dishes missing. A real confusing ordering method....he said to select what we wanted, and that we were #27. I saw other people get food brought to them, but for us, he just yelled out "27," and laid out whole dishes full of dim sum varietites, where the three of us (as well as other patrons) started eating. We selected about 6 different types of dim sum plus rice, and I know for a fact he didn't put 6 different types of dim sum.

Naw, now confidently leaning toward a 2. The fried rice was not cooked properly...
How can rice be mushy, yet the carrots in the rice be undercooked?
author: Dan W.

description: Visiting from Orange County. Had to try "street" Chinese food, Uncle Peter did a phenomenal job making me feel right at home. He brought energy, entertainment, and joy to our table. The food is also fantastic, second to none in my opinion. Very pleased with both our experience (service) and food!
author: J.R S.

description: This was a great experience and the customer service was phenomenal! We definitely recommend for future use!
author: Kathlene M.

description:
The first warning was when the owner was arguing with customers who had gotten there before us over how big of a tip he was given. The second was when the roast duck I ordered was completely cold. The rest of the meal was tolerable, aside from shrimp dumplings and egg rolls that were blatantly out of the box. When I couldn't stomach the food any longer, I asked for a to-go box and received styrofoam-- which is ILLEGAL in San Francisco, since you can't recycle or compost it.

The thing that really made me angry enough to write this review, however, was the fact that the man tried to cheat us. He initially charged us $42.50. When we did the calculations ourselves, it came out to $32.50. When he redid his calculations, surprise, surprise, he got the same number. But of course, he rounded up to $33.

Please, please, save your money and do not go here. The food is terrible, the place is unhygienic, and you will be overcharged on your bill if you don't double check.
author: Mercedes T.

description:
This guy is awesome! He is soooo friendly! Sooo attentive. For that he gets five stars. 

The all you can eat dim sum or ALL YOU CAN NOT EAT dim sum for $5.99? Not good at all. Bland. The siumai needs more structure. It looked like its about to fall apart while just staring at it. Extra $1+ for hot tea. The fried rice? Sigh. Needs more sodium! 

We accidentally ended up walking inside his place because Delicous Dim Sum next door closed early at 7pm. Gah! If we just walked further down there was plenty of other 4-5 stars dim sum heaven. 

On the other hand. It was such a blast. We tried to actually decipher his style of business and we finally ate. We sat there with two kinds of music blaring. Chinese near where Mr Lee was and hip hop where we're eating. 

Bad food but really great service, but foodies go where good food is. So not going back. Ever! 

This is one of those reviews I feel bad about the low rating. The guy is really great :(
author: Janet D.

description:
I've given my fair share of one star Yelp reviews and I've never felt bad about them (often quite angered, actually). In this case, I feel bad because the owner (Dick Lee?) seems really nice. Yet, he's gotta know that his food is extremely disgusting, right?! So he's doing this on purpose? Luring people in with all you can eat at a cheap price, knowing no one would ever ask for seconds or go back?

I've walked by this place several times and was always enticed by the all you can eat for $5.99 sign. The pictures looked good and authentic. I finally had the displeasure of eating here today. It did take a while to get the food, so I was reading this place's Yelp review and thinking to myself, "How bad can it be?" 

Just a quick side note: I've bought egg tarts from this place before, to-go, the ones in the display window. And while they were extremely bland, they weren't by any means disgusting. And also as background, I'm Chinese, I've had dim sum all over the Bay Area and in Hong Kong. 

So back to my all you can eat: He charged me $8 per person because it was dinner. Fine, an extra $2; no big deal. We did have to wait a while for the food, but that's fine as well, since the sign said everything was made fresh. He also served it to us (brought all the dishes to our table).

When all the food finally came, it was the most unappealing, most disgusting, barely edible, worst dim sum I've ever had! This is NOT an exaggeration at all. (1) The fried rice was essentially old rice, corn, lettuce pieces, and salt. This was not a deal-breaker, since I've had similar caliber of fried rice elsewhere in Chinatown. (2) The shrimp dumplings were shaped like little pieces of candy and looked / tasted nothing like shrimp dumplings at dim sum places. They're not even shrimp! They're more like a tiny, elongated fish balls. (3) The pork buns were mostly bun with little shreds of dried pork; all you can taste is the bun. (4) The pork dumplings were purple colored meat! (5) We were served these complimentary yellow-colored cookies, which he said was made out of flour, eggs, and sugar. We had one bite and they were so bitter / horrible tasting; they tasted like they were made of chemicals. 

Like other reviewers have mentioned, I am also shocked at how terrible food tastes here. It's amazing / comical that in this day and age in America, a restaurant can make food this bad. It takes real effort to make food so horrific-tasting. 

I've never had food taste so bad that it's not edible (at least not in the US). We discreetly threw away a good portion of our food, obviously didn't ask for seconds. It is no wonder that for such a cheap all you can eat, there are no other diners inside the restaurant. I wouldn't come back if it was free! I think he's banking on people paying the $6 or $8, serve them tiny portions of disgusting food knowing they'd not ask for seconds, and make their money on luring in suckers for a one-time deal. Paying even $6 on the crap they call food is still a huge profit margin for them. I bet this is how they're staying in business.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Wow 
The food is made fresh and it's absolutely a must to  do when in Chinatown.
It takes a while for the food to come out but it's well worth the wait.
Everything comes out fresh and HOT !
author: Anthony N.

description: Best food, best service! So glad we stopped buy here! The owner is very nice and friendly. This is a little gem in The Chinatown! Come visit and enjoy :)
author: Felicia B.

description: This place is horrible. Somehow $27 worth of food went up to $42.. not only did every meal literally came cold and damn near uncooked, ordered fried rice and it literally tasted like plain old white rice. Don't come eat here, it's a rip off and it's simply not worth it. Quality over quantity!!
author: Travis B.

description: Super nice owner. We ordered an assortment of pastries... they took awhile to arrive (because the owner was heating them up), but were well worth the wait! The owner served us personally & was very helpful when selecting what we wanted.
author: Suzanne H.

description:
I was backpacking across country last year and while in San Francisco my money began to look pretty slim. I was blown away to find anything all you can eat for less than $10 in San Francisco. To my surprise it was even decent enough quality! Now, this alone would not be enough to win a 5 star rating. What really won me over was the owner. Never have I felt more welcomed in a business!

We were three dirty travelers with huge backpacks. Our clothes were stained and we had not showered in weeks. We looked a wreck. Many other places would have thrown us out. Instead we were not only welcomed with a smile but told that we could eat and stay all day if we wanted to. We could not believe the hospitality offered to us!

Needless to say we remember this establishment fondly and tell everyone about it. The food was good, the atmosphere was welcoming, and the staff was someone with a huge heart.
author: Kristina K.

description: This place has to be THE BEST Dim Sum in town. I have eaten Chinese and Dim Sum my entire life and the quality of service, pace of service and quality of food is FANTASTIC!!! All you can eat prices with DELICIOUS food and the owner is ADORABLE
author: Kimberley B.

description: I mean its not gourmet but the prices are hella cheap. If ur on a budget and looking for a cheap meal you can fill urself up with decent food here for cheap. When i came here that had 5 pork buns for a dollar so basically spend 2 dollars for a days worth of meals the next day. Owner is pretty nice too
author: Dylan L.

description: The owner was very kind to us!! Not only did he bring out all of our food, but he also gave us free samples of other foods (on the house) which was very thoughtful. I thought that the food was great and so was the service. I believe that this shop deserves more than a 2 star rating because it definitely is worth more than that
author: Kristina L.

description:
The Skinny: I wouldn't eat here even if you handsomely paid me. 

Environment:
So we were walking down the street in Chinatown looking for dim sum. We weren't able to find a place that was opened except for the insanely large and obstructive signage here at Dick Lee Pastry Shop. I'll give it to them that they know how to get your attention. Their signage was very akin to the online pop-ups where it says "Congratulations, we have a winner!". Yeah, no winner. We figured... maybe it can't be that bad since it's in Chinatown amongst the other dim sum places. So we walked in... and it looked like if Subway merged with a street taco place and broke all the food safety regulations. The trays that they used to cook the dim sum were super dirty and all over the place, and even their cash register was just opened up and money was sprawled everywhere without any order. 

Service:
So we came here because the sign outside promoted $6 all-you-can-eat dim sum, which is super attractive when it's in Chinatown. The sign itself looked super beat up like it went through a few tornadoes. When we were seated, the server (is he the owner?) told us we had to go to the front cashier to order. If that's the case, why didn't he take our order to begin with? So we went to the front and placed in our order with the all-you-can-eat menu. He stated that we can order as much as we want. After we finished ordering, he rang us up for more than $40 which made absolutely no sense! We pointed it out and he said that he didn't know we wanted to do the all-you-can-eat. So he fixed it and gave us our number and had us sit and wait after we paid. We waited for a good 40 minutes, and we had to be somewhere so we went back up and asked for a refund since he didn't even start on our order yet. He stated that they don't do refunds, but he will pack our food to-go. We were at the register and waiting for him to get our food to-go, but he ended up going away to serve 3 or 4 other tables. We had to call out and remind him again that he still owed us our food and emphasize we had to leave. He said okay and he continued to run around in the back doing who knows what (but clearly not getting our food). We ended up leaving without our food because it wasn't worth the possibility of contracting food poisoning or some food-borne disease that we potentially could have gotten due to how filthy the kitchen was.

Food:
N/A

Overall: I wish I could give a 0/5, but Yelp forces me to put at least 1 star. Yeah... don't go here. You've been warned MANY times from the other reviewers. I'm just adding to the statistics.
author: Tony D.

description:
Run away, run away if you want to avoid explosive diarrhea and food poisoning.
Food: gross and gross, don't know how there are reviews that stated this place have fresh dim sum, OMG, don't even know where they make their food, the kitchen is filthy and it looks like no one touches it for weeks.
Service: extremely bad service. The guy told us to write down our order and he'll be right back in 1 minute....but that meant he didn't even bother looking at us or coming back at all until we went straight to the front counter. There was no waiter/waitress at all, it was the an one-man restaurant. He also tricked us into ordering the fried rice and noodles since it was not on their regular dim sum menu so it was expensive.
Atmosphere: this looks and feels like a shop in rural area in Mexico. Dirty tables and chairs, with the food aisles like in Subway yet without the 'freshness' of Subway.
Overall: BAD BAD BAD. Do not go here. If yelp has the option to give ZERO star, this place would be the winner.
author: Dyala N.

description: If possible I would give this place -5 stars. Firstly, the owner is UNETHICAL!! The menu put $4 and he charged $14 on my card. Because he used a square abs intentionally avoided asking my signature, I only knew I'd after the fact. The thing is if one is wicked and shameless to scrape anything they possibly can. There's a HUGE doubt about the ingredient they use, the sanitation of the cooking area( the kitchen is gross, but most are in Chinatown so not particularly  criticizing that here). I ordered beef noodle soup. And the beef is PINK(don't know what beef they use but it's actually cooked ) and RUBBER texture!!!! Seriously, I eat Chinese food on a regular basis. This is the WORST. For your own health, safty, and well-being. Seriously AVOID this dump at all cost.
author: Leanne L.

description: You cannot beat the value offered here. No-nonsense service and great food. This restaurant is a gem of Chinatown.
author: Derek W.

description: What a steal. Great food, excellent service, amazing dim sum special. Ask for the hot sauce to dip everything in. Nicest people, great music from what looks like a 1992 Hewlett Packard sets the tone for a true China town experience. Can't wait to come back for the tasty food and stellar experience.
author: D H.

description: Wow,I am not sure about the positive reviews I see hear on Yelp. They may be fake , or people who have never had good Dim Sum before. Here is our story. I wanted to show a little bit of San Francisco to my wife, who has only been in the USA for 11 months, what it is like in Chinatown San Francisco. Well I was not so hungry, but my wife saw a sign that says All You Can Eat for $5.99. At first, I thought, hmmm, maybe should stay away, but then I said , lets see. Well, I should have seen these posts on Yelp first, but I was a bit tired, and not thinking to well. Anyway we come in, and only one couple was there at first. We sat down, and about 20 people came out of nowhere. The waiter ,and owner showed us a menu, and we asked about the $5.99 All You Can Eat sign, and he said because it is a holiday (Labor Day), the price is $7.99. We almost left(and should of), but we had to use the restroom. Anyway, we wait, and wait, and our asked to write down what we would like. So I write down Egg Rolls, Pork Sui Mia, Seafood Sui Mui, and Shark Fin Dim Sum. We asked for 2 bottles of water $2 each, and Coke Zero. He came back with the water bottles, and Diet Pepsi. As he walked away, I politely said excuse me, but I ordered Coke Zero, and went away and came back with Diet Coke(all well I tried). They guy looks overwhelmed as new customers poor in, and I can understand the pressure, but not how he reacted. His wife seems to work with him. We received the egg rolls first. They were cold almost as ICE. I said they were cold, and brought back ones that seemed to come from a microwave. Anyway , they were not so good. And they guy helps customers that came long after us, with them getting their food first. OK, I get it, this guy is a one man operation. We finally get something that looks like Pork Sui Mai. As we are eating , my wife and I look at each other, like what the hell is this look. Instantly my belly starts aching. Then guy brings us Pork Buns, which we did not order. They were mostly bun, but no too bad. Then what looks another portion of Pork Sui Mai comes, (not the Seafood Sui Mai we were expecting). It tasted exactly the same. Yuck. I get the bill on an Ipad with my VISA. I see $26.00 , which I didn't think to much of at the time, but then as I was leaving, I thought wait a minute, two All You Can Eat, times 2 $15.98, two waters $4.00, and one Diet Coke??? , I don't understand, a $6 dollar coke, or tax of some kind. Bill didn't show tax. And I hit the 15% TIP icon. Well I didn't receive a receipt. Until I looked at my email. Somehow $3.90 tip changed to $6.5. We left without even finishing our meal. You know the old saying, if it seem to be too good to true, stay away. Stay far far far away from this place. I know it is hard to have a business going, but this is not that way. My stomach is still hurting three days later.
author: JohnJack P.

description: I wanted to try something new during my lunch hours instead of eating rice everyday at Chinatown;  So I decided to come to Dick Lee. That was the most worst mistake ever in the history of my lunch hour. I came for their $5.99 dim sum special for all you can eat. I was so surprised that you can eat unlimited dim sum for $5.99; So I decided to come in and give it a try. I walked in and before I could even sit down, the person in the front counter said "Pay money before sit". I was so surprised and mad at the same time. I paid my 6$, sat down, grabbed the plate he gave me and started grabbing dim sum. I got pork siu mai, hargow, fried rice, and fortune cookies. The siu mai meat tastes sour and bitter. MEAT IS NOT SUPPOSED TO TASTE SOUR! The hargow was hard as a rock with small, WAIT. VERY SMALL chunks of shrimp. The fried rice was also cold and hard with a lot of oil buried deep into the rice. The fourtune cookie though was pretty good. I ate 10. Hey. I did not come here to eat 10 fortune cookies for lunch. After 20 minutes of eating, my stomach started to hurt very badly. I rushed to the restroom, sat down and had diarrhea. Guess what's the best part? There wasn't any paper for me to wipe my butt. How nice. I had to use my own tissues to wipe my butt after having a stomach ache for the food I paid $5.99 for. So let me see.. I paid $5.99 to poop out their food and lost 1 whole hour of my lunch time. I WARNED YOU! DO NOT COME TO DICK LEE PASTRY IF YOU WANT TO HAVE THE SAME EXPERIENCE AS ME! YOU'VE ALL BEEN WARNED. I AM DEFINITELY NOT COMING BACK. EVER!!!
author: Jonathan Z.

description:
I would score O if i could. The food tasted nasty and questionable. They used toilet paper as napkins for their customers! Toilet paper?! Who does that?! 
They took forever to serve us our food, over charged me!! Crooks!! Never again! Gross!!!!!
author: Jeana M.

description:
SteMedbyellow cake was not good and dry at lost parts.

All you can eat dim sum with about only 10 or less selections

We ordered the dim sum we wanted but they didn't even make everything to order...
Honestly the beef and pork balls and dim sum was not good at all:( even the shrimp ones. Flavor tasted as if they used dirty water . 
Sure the guy was nice but the food was not appetizing at all. 
Fried rice... I can make great fried rice and even a mediocre one would taste better . 
Sorry but it can definitely be better. Love the service but food and flavor a definitely need help.
author: Tiffany S.

description: for the price, you can't go wrong with place. a true china town experience. 1 server, very friendly. maybe even extremely happy. my favorite thing was the pork bao. you can't go wrong with bottomless pork bao.
author: Ness R.

description:
Zero stars for this restaurant.  The owner puts on a fake smile and lures you in but he is a dishonest man with no conscience to serve such poor quality food to his customers.  The shrimp dumpling did not have any shrimp and ingredients we cannot identify and with lots of food coloring.  All items in the steamer was dried up.  We also ordered a wonton soup and BBQ duck with rice.  The wonton soup came with 7 extremely small size dumplings, it was embarrassing, it costed $6.25.  The BBQ duck was nothing but bones and a sad scoop of rice, it costed $7.99.  The bbq duck felt like scraps and we wouldn't be surprised that they served us food from garbage other people threw out.  The food is NOTHING like the photos displayed in the store front.  The sanitation is questionable.  The tea that came out of the pot had colorful soap bubbles that we did not dare to drink.  On the ground near the self serve water/tea/hot water are two large piles of dirty dishes that customers would place after they finished eating.  

As we started to question everything about this business, we started calculating the cost of our food.  We first paid  3x $5.99 buffet and he over charged us exactly by $1 (instead of $19.50, he charged us $20.50), he first denied and said $20.50 was correct, but we broke it down with tax and it was obvious we are right.  It's unbelievable as owner he would not know by heart the cost of $5.99 for 3 people with tax is.  That means he's always overcharging customers and he was denying instead of apologizing his wrong doing.  It's basic math, idiot, you cannot argue it.

DO NOT COME HERE.  It's a tourist trap, they are cheating people and it's sad to have such a business on this busy chinatown street.
author: Yvonne L.

description: This dimsum place is a joke. The food is terrible. Its really a tourist trap. Go elsewhere for fast food dimsum or pay a little more for authentic dimsum.
author: Alex Z.

description: I got the 4.95 for Thai tea boba and any 3 dim sum but wow the quality is the same as the price. Cheap.... BBQ pork bun had more bread than pork. Shrimp dumpling had pieces of shell inside and meat veggie dumpling was not good. It's not good quality.
author: Misa I.

description: I kind of wondered for the rest of the day if I would not feel well, but it's been hours, and I'm feeling fine, so I guess it was okay :). I had the barbeque buns (bao), and they were just okay. I've had a lot better in Denver. For being in Chinatown, I wasn't super impressed.
author: Tarrah T.

description:
This place is one of the larger dim sum establishments in the Chinatown area, in terms of canopy and frontage size.

Parking is available on the street in front.

The inside looks somewhat clean, but the dining area is more of a storage area if anything.

One interesting piece of decor inside is the really dirty ramen bowl that has been converted into a tissue box.  Creative and ghetto.

They advertise all you can eat dim sum for only $6, but honestly I would have reservations about this.  The dim sum is not very good at all in terms of taste or flavour.  I had trouble finishing my plate.  (disclaimer: I had the a la carte)  May I suggest Delicious, up the street.
author: Edward L.

description: Great, food, even better price and it's all you can eat. Super nice lady running it. Good place to grab dinner without spending too much. It's a little small but it has character and a nice quiet vibe. Definitely coming again
author: Mitchel S.

description: I was quite shocking when I saw the overall bad review of this restaurant but still decided to give a try since I already inside the restaurant. I ordered 1 order of shrimp dumpling, 1 order of custard bun, and 1 order of $5.99 all you can eat dim sum. I was charged $10.99 in total. The food is fresh and hot, way better than what it says on most review. I don't understand why this restaurant gets terrible reviews so I asked the owner and he said he doesn't understand either and cannot control what people wrote on yelp. He showed me those post-it notes on the wall with reviews customers wrote about the restaurant. The owner is very friendly to me and also offered free tea to me. I definitely will come back again!
author: Cly C.

description: The food is delicious and the boss is so friendly. Every time we come to eat can be so full that we do not need to eat dinner! Especially like the siu mai and dumpling, very tasty. My friend and I enjoy the food very much and the service here is great! Definitely to come next time.
author: Angela M.

description:
The food is what you expect for $6 all you can eat. The shrimp dumplings are pretty good. I ate mostly shrimp dumplings and the fried rice, and I got so full from just a small plate. The lotus buns are cute and delicious, and the taro buns are good if they're hot and fresh. 
Sui Mai is bigger than I see from our normal dim sum place in Chinatown LA. I didn't eat them, but my parents said they tasted pretty good.
The atmosphere is kinda sketchy, and I saw a couple flies around the tables. Kind of gross. Also kind of confusing seating thing because you wait for the guy to hand you the paper plate and you pick up what you want yourself. But the guy is really nice.
author: Julia S.

description: The owner is super friendly--a Chinatown gem. And the food is good for the price--it's $6 for all-you-can-eat dim sum. If you come in with the right expectations, you'll walk out satisfied.
author: Yara E.

description: Though the ordering system was confusing at first the overall experience was fantastic. The gentleman behind the counter was nothing but that, a gentleman. One of the girls in our party had a dietary restriction and he pointed out what would work for her and even made her something special without asking and brought it to our table. Food was good but the man waiting on us really made this place something special. It was a great way to start our trip to San Francisco.
author: Alison W.

description: Save your time and money and not come here... I came here just once and it was no good. The Dim Sum were blah and the fried rice were way too salty. Won-ton were average tho. The owner was nice, but sometimes that doesn't work. under $10 maybe a good deal, but may send you to the hospital and have high medical bills.
author: Peter N.

description:
This is a prime example of what happens when you don't have internet to Yelp places to eat on vacation. YELP PLACES BEFORE YOU EAT, PEOPLE.

My friends and I were walking around Chinatown during the evening, primarily looking for a cute little bakery that was still open to buy cute little Asian baked goods. The word "Pastry" on the banner caught our eyes, so we meandered over to check it out. We were checking out the display case out front (lo and behold, NOT a bakery), when we made our gravest mistake: we were lured into the shop by the nice lady and the sign "All you can eat dim sum, $5.99 + tax." Sounds like a good deal, right? The nice lady caught us in her net, and thus we were forced to oblige to some dim sum (darn our Asian manners).

Oh dear. Where to start:
- The egg tart was a mystery green color instead of the usual yellow. What...? The adventurous ones in the group tasted it and couldn't figure out what it was. Yikes.
- The outside of the har gow was tough and plastic-y, as if it had been sitting there in the steamer for quite awhile (it probably was). Same issue with the BBQ pork bun.
-  The meat in the siu mai was still pink (eek). One of my friends pointed out the pile of ground pork being mixed near the door - this meat was also an unusually pink color, so we decided that they probably put food coloring in the meat, so the meat in the siu mai was probably cooked thoroughly (at least that's what we told ourselves).

Fortunately for us, we received some exceptional service since our one Cantonese friend was able to speak to the Cantonese owners. The nice lady saw that they were low on fried rice and cooked up a whole new batch just for us, and personally brought out a plate of the fried rice to our table. Unfortunately for us, this meant we had to finish the whole thing (darn our Asian manners again!). It was decent fried rice, though.

Conclusion: not a bakery, and not a good place for dim sum.
author: Caroline N.

description: I would recommend this place if you really want to lose weight because first it's raw and second you going to go home with food poison! That's mean you're going to puke your whole heart! I grabbed me an egg custard and it was a fresh egg yolk straight in my throat! Disgusting!!! If you want some quick money then eat there and sue!! I am disappointed!!!!
author: William F.

description: This is the worst dim sum place in China Town San Francisco. We tried it because my son wanted to eat dim sum but from the price to the place, to food, everything was so bad. I gave 1 star but I wouldn't if I could. The price says $5.99 but he charges $7 per person and he said because of tax. How could it be tax? The service was super lousy, the Chinese guy was so bad. Doesn't know any manners and so rude to customers. I will not recommend this place and I hope someone from the state will come and check this place if they are really reporting the sales tax, and if they're kitchen is clean. This place needs closed .... please calling all authorities please come to this place and audit so it can get closed. They served us seafood dumpling and it tasted like it's been cooked for a week, so tough and overcooked. I hated this place that I felt I wasted my money for 2 pcs of sharks fun that tasted like a rotten meat. Please begging authorities to please check this place and get it closed for people's sake.
author: Carol B.

description: Food was not bad for the price, but the ordering method was confusing because you didn't really get what you order. The Siu Mai looked oddly pink. Very nice man at the counter.
author: Tim L.

description: Extremely sweet people! very friendly and welcoming. pricing is great and the environment is fun. they took a little long to deliver the egg rolls so he gave us extra and said we can get as many more for no charge. I would absolutely eat here again. such a wonderful place! and super wonderful people!
author: Kayley C.

description:
As you may have noticed the Yelp site was experiencing technical difficulties yesterday. So for about two hours, I wandered around Chinatown without my favorite city guide. 

It was overwhelming! I didn't know where to go, and all I wanted to do was just to stuff my mouth with some sweet, sweet dumplings. 

I observed an old Chinese lady steaming big baskets of dumplings outside of her restaurant and paused for a minute to take it all in. Before I knew it, she had guided me in with the crook of her elbow, sat me down, and recommended a few dishes to try. I was a bit tired, super hungry, and raised not to object my elders so I sat down without a complaint. 

The specials she offered were dirt cheap. Think beef and broccoli with fried rice, an egg roll, and wonton soup for $5.75 or a beef curry bowl over hand pulled noodles for $4.75. And a dim sum plate for $1.50. What a steal! 

When the food came out, I immediately lost my appetite. The soup came out in the crustiest bowl known to man. The silverware seemed dirty as well, as if it was just rescued by the Boxcar children in the town dump. I tried not to be uppity about the situation....I've dined in third world countries before and had some of the best food of my life out of old, crusty bowls. But this definitely was not the case here. The dim sum that came out was hard, crusty and falling a part. I was able to eat one dumpling and two bites of the curry bowl before I gave up. This place was straight up nasty and the super sticky soy sauce bottle didn't help either. I know I have already used the adjective "crusty" about a bazillion times in this review already but that's the best way to describe this joint.  

The one redeeming quality about the restaurant was how genuinely happy the man and woman who owned the shop were to have us eating in their restaurant. I saw a sign that said "No refunds after ordering" which I thought was funny at the beginning of my trip but totally made sense by the end.

Once Yelp started working again a few hours later, I checked to see if my experience was typical for this restaurant only to find out that this restaurant was recently sued by the City of San Francisco for forcing their immigrant workers to work 14 hour days for WAAAAYYYY less than minimum wage. No wonder they were so happy to have some business! 

Stay far, far away from this place!
author: Kimberly S.

description: Service was the best.  The owner gave us extra stuff at no charge! The food was delicious. We will definitely come back! Egg rolls, Siu Mai, duck, rice noodles and beef...all great!
author: T P.

description:
AVOID!!!!!  DISGUSTING FOOD.   I'm a San Franciscan & eat out quite often and in neighborhoods all over the city.

Was walking around Chinatown & saw the "All you can eat" sign.  Thought, why not?  Had dim sum across the street the day before and it was delicious.  So decided to try this place for kicks.  Biggest mistake ever.  If I could rate this a negative five I would.  I think the positive reviews must be posted by folks who don't know good Chinese food.  There was a very long wait time.  I asked for tap water & he immediately grabbed bottled water & rang up the bill.  Fortunately the water was a life saver.  

After a 45 minute wait he motioned to us & told us the dim sum was ready in the steamers.  He then quickly turned around & faced the TV.   As others stated food looked nothing like the menu he showed us.  

We served ourselves the various dim sum.  No napkins.  He has toilet paper rolls for napkins.   So we went back to our table.  Took a bite out of one, then spit it out.  All the dim sum appeared undercooked & possibly made from spam.  Even though the dim sum was large, it was disgusting; a greasy meaty mess.  I spit out every dim sum I tried.  I threw away all pieces in the trash close to the table.  Perhaps that's why it's there so conveniently?

I figured I might as well try the pork bun.  How bad could it be?  Horrible!  Weird tasting dough & a tiny speck of meat inside.  Spit that out too & threw away in trash.

It is "All you can eat" because ALL you can eat is one bite before you spit it out.  

If you can call this food, it is bad quality food and tastes horrible.  It is deceptive that he shows you stock photography of dim sum, but serves something else.  He is nice to the prospective customer until you pay, then not so nice after one pays.

I agree with the other posts.  Stay away from this place unless you like bad food, a long wait & don't care if you get sick.  This place should be shut down.  Someone does need to call the Health Department indeed.
author: Zela N.

description:
I finally stopped at this place because I was in search of Egg Custard Tarts and with the Chinese New Year parade about to start, it was too packed to even decide where else to go. The streets were packed with people.

I suppose I could've been wary of the flock of people giving into their 5.99 AYCE dim sum deal. 

3 Egg Tarts are all I bought from their little outside stand, they were .80 cents each, warm, flaky and of course eggy. They were tolerable, definitely not the best Egg Tart I've ever had and the crust was starting to disintegrate into my hand the more bites I took into it. The custard was a bit too eggy for my liking, but what can you do?

I took one look inside the restaurant and it was a no go. Cafeteria styled seating, steaming dim sum in trays, styrofoam and plastic cutlery. Sketchy McSketch, if you ask me.
author: Janet N.

description:
Dick Lee's. 
Not that bad as people say it is. Was actually enjoyable when my friends and I went there a few days ago while visiting San Francisco. What do people expect for paying only $5.99? The reason why I beleive the reviews are bad is because San Francisco has a high standard on dimsum food, since there are so many in the area. If you came to visit, it's not that bad. Just like how buffet food is compared to authentic restaurant food, the same applies here. Some of the food there does look a little suspect, but hey the sui mai and the pork buns were on point. 

4/5 for the food. What did you expect for $5.99?

2/5 for the after effects
(all of the friends that came with me had a battle in the bathroom) could have been from others things we ate before though*

5/5 for the service "Peter" provided. His vibe and encouragement of eating more and staying longer made us feel welcome. It seemed like he really wants to satify his customers. 

Overall its worth a try, might be a memoriable experience.
author: Tony N.

description:
It was our fault for not checking here before eating, what a mistake! I Should have known it was bad because it was peak lunch hour, and no one was inside. First off, the dim sum buffet is $7 even, and it's pretty bad: 

The "shrimp" dumpling had no noticeable shrimp inside. Instead, there was some mushy yellow filling. I tried to ignore the look and focus on the taste to give it a fair shot. Still not good! The Sui Mai also tasted bad, and was undercooked. I mean it was completely pink inside, though my friend suggested it could have been food coloring... 

The best part about my meal was the complementary water with lemon flavor. That was it. Something also to be aware of for clean freaks, this place has a health rating of 42/100 (the standard is 90-100, and I have only seen very few other places below that!)! And you definitely get that vibe. 

I would definitely recommend eating elsewhere!
author: Graeme S.

description:
Dick Lee Pastry Shop offers all you can eat dim sum buffet (9.99?)

sounds good ..until you read what's  included
-mostly buns,  doughy pastries,
-not har gow, siu mai, crepes.

not such a good deal afterall.

notes:
-place looks like a dive
-not much appetite in a divey atmosphere.
author: Victor G.

description:
0 STARS! By far worst place I have ever eat at in the Bay Area. At first you think of how cheap the buffet and sounds like a great deal! But once you walk in and look at the food you realize why it is so cheap to begin with. This place will gross you out to the point of not knowing what you are actually eating. 

Walking in I was starving but after questioning the quality of the food....and what its actually made of just went to McDonalds instead. Worst experience I have ever had. Only fun was criticising the food to the point of it becoming comical, I don't know how this place hasn't been shut down yet.

Like someone else put it "best dog food I've ever had"
author: Michael G.

description: For $6 all you can eat dim sum, this place is pretty good. Keep in mind that this is low quality dim sum, but is incredibly cheap. The owner is nice and seemed enthusiastic about his job and encouraged everyone to eat more. I'd come here again.
author: Anthony P.

description:
After a long day, on our way back to the car, I noticed that Dick Lee was still open and had to stop by for baked pork buns and egg tarts.  I ended up also picking up some frozen, steamed red bean buns.  Everything was good, and for a good price.  

Pork buns were HUGE and the red bean buns had a good filling to bun ratio.  Can't say the egg tarts were that great, since I could taste the lard in it, more than the egg or sugar.

The girl behind the counter was friendly and helpful.  If it weren't for her, I wouldn't have known about the frozen, red bean buns.
author: Audrey C.

description: Some of the best value for money I've gotten in San Francisco. It's 7/10 in terms of quality of food. 9/10 for service. 7/10 for wait time. 8/10 for location/convenience. For $5.99 all-you-can-eat, how can you go wrong? Dick lee is a great guy, and the bad reviews here are highly exaggerated. Food is not perfect, but for the quality & quantity you get, should be at least $10-$15. You cannot beat $5.99.
author: Logan S.

description: I saw 6 dollar AYCE dim sum and I could not resist. me and my friend stumbled upon this place by accident... We walk in and get greeted by a very nice man. He was super friendly and gave us a good vibe.. However... the food..... the food was beyond horrible... everything tasted as if they steamed their food with sewer water. Everything tasted off, the beef, the chicken, the seafood, the rice, the buns. If you blind folded me and had me try that I would never ever guess it was dim sum food. I was so scared of getting food poisoning after eating here. DO NOT COME HERE. YOU WILL REGRET IT.
author: Thomas N.

description: Only pro is its so cheap even if you eat little that i do, you didnt lose much. Fried rice was terrible..avoid it if you can. Only trying once. Never again
author: Tam C.

description:
Sesame balls for $1...and they're huge!  Just passing through with a friend visiting for the weekend and decided to pop in for a pastry.  Was looking for an egg custard tart but the sesame balls were the first thing to catch my eye and they were definitely large enough to tide me over until getting to our next meal so we grabbed a few to go.  

Friendly man at the front helped us out and served us...would totally go back next time I pass through and try another yummy dessert!
author: Laura S.

description: can I give "dislike" or negative star? worst dim sum ever. For $5.99, you're served with very lousy dim sum, some undercook, icy frozen. terrible service, dirty place. I have goose bump everytime I think of my trip there, avoid it of all cost!
author: Joyce T.

description: so gross. tourist trap. the meat is not fresh, buns are not fresh. can't believe I wasted $7 a person here. their pay a la carter food isn't bad, but the ayce is really, really my biggest regret this week. the owner should have a conscience to not serve this food! :(
author: Maggie G.

description: This place open once a week and the food they serve is old. They don't attract the local cuz we know all about them, food sucks, mistreating employees, and it's very dirty, zero star, restaurant rating is "0". Stay away from this place, don't get sucker in.
author: Mad N.

description: Good dim sum here!! The boss and the staff are very nice. They serve people with kind attitude and always with smiling face. The "all you can eat" is worth-eating. All the food was fresh made. Especially recommend Hong Kong people to go. The boss can speak in both English and Cantonese. Apart from dim sum, the soy milk made by the boss was really fantasy. Go and try it out!
author: Tracy Y.

description:
It's been about five years since I have been to Dick Lees and there have been some changes to the restaurant.
The food is better than the last time I was here. They now make everything to order, instead of en masse. This may cause a delay in getting your all-you-can-eat dim sum, but is now comes out hot.
The ayce menu is limited to about 8 items or so. It does not include all of the dim sum available. Some of it is tasty, some of it is not. The shrimp har gow is a pass. I think they are using small dried shrimp instead of fresh and the taste is quite strong and fishy. The fill in the har gow is almost nonexistent.
The dining experience here is a bit bazar. To keep their cost low, about $9 for ayce, you must buss your own table, pick up your food a few dishes at a time and get your chop sticks from a bucket.
The owner is affable and friendly, but if you are into clean and tidy, this is not the restaurant for you. Most health department designations go from "A" to "D". if there were an "F", it would be here. The benches you sit on are clean enough, but that's about it.
To make sure the food is hot, the owner gives you just a few dishes at a time. You finish what you have, give him back the dirty dishes and he returns a few more of what you have ordered to you. Service=none. You do it all yourself.
Is there value here? Yes, if you are looking for cheap and filling without a lot of quality. 
Am I going to go back soon? Not in my life time. There are too many other places to have dim sum in china town. 
*see my review on Good Mong Kok Bakery
author: Jay S.

description: Worst $20.00 I've ever spent. The owner was super nice so he deserves a star but the food....no
author: Aaron L.

description:
$6 all you can eat dim sum only gets you 2/10 edible "food" items, a hearty stomachache and sustained bathroom visits for the next 24 hours.

Cheers!
author: Kat K.

description: The owner was nice. All I got from here were egg custard tart and sesame balls to go. The egg custard was not good at all. Really gooey and without true egg flavor. The sesame balls were a bit better, but nothing special.
author: James W.

description:
$6 for all you can eat dim sum?  Gotta try it, right?  Well, it was worth trying once.

Pros:
Polite and helpful cashier.
They have seating inside!
The pork siu mai and shrimp har gau were very good.
They have hot tea, perfect for San Francisco.

Not-so-pros:
Not as many of the "better" dim sum made but many rows of the cheaper stuff.
The single plate they give you gets filthy pretty quickly.

Truth be told, $6 in Chinatown, San Francisco can buy more dim sum than most people can finish in one sitting.  Yes, different story in Honolulu but in San Fran, may as well order exactly what you want, get full, and write glowing Yelp reviews instead of okay ones.
author: Eric M.

description:
Well, this is what happens when you don't check Yelp before entering a restaurant. My friend and I were looking for a cheap/good place to eat, and well, we got half of what we wanted. It was certainly cheap, but just awful. 

The fried rice was decent, but everything else was awful and/or gross. Please, stay away. The quality of the food was not good at all, and we were both super surprised that we didn't get sick.
author: Lesley C.

description: Horrible food, meat looks like the pink slime I saw a feature on, on tv. Sounds cheap but $6.99 ($1 extra to use a card) is a lot to pay for shitty fried rice when every other offering is inedible.
author: Will J.

description: Ahh Dick Lee's.  I was lured here by the siren call of the $5.99 AYCE Dim Sum option and completely forgot to check any previous Yelp review of this establishment.  But alas, as my poor unsuspecting friends and I fell prey to the seduction we soon realized that you get what you pay for.  The dim sum was tasteless and stale and I believe there was a fly of some sort taking a swim in the soy sauce bottle.  The owner was very nice though, but unfortunately that offers little recompense for the terrible food.  To top it all off, there was the delightful aroma of dog sh** lingering in the air; cutting short our interlude (and our misery) at Dick Lee's.
author: Caitlyn Y.

description:
I spent about 5 hours walking around san fran, and about 2 hours was spent walking past colorful chinatown eateries with chinese characters that all started to look the same to me after a while.  

Exhausted, and hungry, I then saw the $5.99 for all you can eat dim sum, got super excited, and dragged friend inside.

I should've known better.  And it might be a good thing that my non-asian friend isn't that picky about his food so I didn't feel that guilty/embarrassed about repping my supposed knowledge about dim sum well after talking about it for so long.

-50 item buffet? More like just a couple of sub-par dim sum choices, and then a short line (about 10 choices) of very typical Chinese dishes, including egg drop soup/wonton soup/hot and sour soup... and soggy looking french fries.  However, you can ask them to make other stuff for you for no extra charge... unfortunately I'm not the type of person who can recite the secret chinese menu on the spot.
-very simple set-up, one disposable plate per person, you dump out your leftovers in the big trash can next to the mini buffet line and put food back in.  not very hygenic.
-I should've known that it was a trap when I saw the place filled with about 90% of non-chinese speaking/tourist looking people, when the million other restaurants in Chinatown are filled with true asians.

The nice looking old asian man tricked me into paying for water.  I should've known better than to assume it wouldn't cost extra :(
author: Tian Q.

description:
If you are like me, not Chinese and only eat dumplings specifically siu mai then this place is for you. I seriously did not see 50 items that was listed to entice guests to come in but for $5.99 all you can eat joint- you can't expect great tasting and quality foods. 

You walk in, you pay, you are then handed foam utensils and eatery platforms: plates, bowl, cup... first up are the  dumplings. Tongs were soaked in water.. good to see that but according to Safety and Sanitation guidelines, that bucket of water must be changed every 4 hours or as needed to prevent contamination. Anyway- the siu mai was good, the beef siu mai was good (beef meatballs) but by all means skip the har gow at all costs. 

Next up were the usual fixings: sautéed tofu (please pass as it was flavorless and probably tasted better uncooked), the chow mein looked incredibly glossy.. not bad but I scarfed down a pint of oil, I am positive. The eggroll was mushy.. looked crispy on the outside and to some degree it was but after the first bite- a pile of mush!! The wonton soup is a must pass.. I repeat.. do not make the same mistake I did.. it's wonton in boiled water. I repeat.. flavorless wontons in boiled water.. the damn thing is not soup! The omelet was good.. that and fries that looked old were the only American selections that I see. 

Garbage cans at the end of the buffet line posed contamination risk.. OMG I did not see that until after I reached at the end. My Diet Cola Shasta was good.. had no idea it was still around! Service was nonexistent but that is expected. Tables were kept in OK conditions.. you are expected to clean up after yourself. The soy sauce isn't available at every table.. I had to reach over another table to grab a bottle. Kudos for the low sodium soy sauce availability. This place accepts non cash payments (MC/Visa/Discover) but a discount (did not indicate how much of a discount) for cash paying guests.  

I passed by this place several million times and glad I tried it but would I go again? No. Great place to go only if you plan to eat siu mai ONLY. For unlimited eating for $5.99 especially in this economy, could you complain? I sort of did but I am just trying to inform others of the dining experience and expectations. I was full for $5.99.
author: Tram N.

description: I ordered flat noodles,  which I saw on a picture menu,  with no prices. I was told they didn't have anymore.  So,  i asked for chow mien, a Coke,  and the all you can eat dim sum for my daughter.  Two women behind me Pedersen the flat noodles and soup.  The women who ordered after me got flat noodles.  A few minutes later, I was called to pick up my order.  What do you know,  flat noodles.  Since the two ladies who can after me were sitting nectar to me,  I looked over at their plate.  They had significantly more than I. (Ordered from the same picture menu,  no variation in order size. ) I then took my plate back to the counter and told the guy that he said their were no flat noodles when I initially ordered.  He said,  " We made them special for you!" I sat down, took one bite,  and the noodles were cold.  I decided not to eat them because,  they were cold,  my page looked sloppily put together,  I first i was told they didn't have them, but the people after me was given their order and their serving was prepared a lot nicer than mine.  My "coke" was a shasta that they charged $1.50 for.  My cold half serving of noodles,  I was charged $8.99. With my daughter's dim sum,  or total came to $18.50.  This place is extremely cluttered.  The guy at the counter stared at me the whole time we were there.  I should not have stayed and ordered food,  let alone,  paid.  It was late, I was tired and just wanted to get something quick to eat and go home.  I will never in life go here again.
author: lashawnte b.

description:
This place.... Ugh. Pls, DO NOT stop and look, DO NOT go in, DO pass by it quickly, or rather.... RUN. 

The place is HORRIBLE, DISGUSTING, UNFORGIVABLE. 

The place is dirty. My hubby who is not a picky eater, did not want to eat here but I was tired, it was late and he said he wanted to eat something. We were in Chinatown, most (if not all) the restaurants are closed, other restaurants has long line and I just want to be on the way home already.

On the way to our car we passed by this place, dirty looking but we had some of the best food in dodgy looking places! So we went it, took a look and saw the $5.95 + tax "All You Can Eat Dim Sum." I told hubby, "Lets just eat here, it's cheap, our car is near, please?" Bad bad bad BAD choice. I was so tired, I didn't even think of yelping it!

Oversalted meat siu mai. Hubby asked, "What kind of meat is this? It doesn't taste like pork, nor beef nor chicken! Dog? Cat?" I don't know what to answer cos I felt so sorry. The same meat filling in ALL dumplings or siu mai.

The buns (char siu of some dodgy meat, red bean and veggies) smells stale and taste rancid! I spit it all out. The owner of the restaurant announced "fresh stir fried veggies!" I went there to grab some quickly. Upon sitting down and picking on the veggies, oh dear Lord, the horror. Those veggies are vegetable parts. You know those bak choy bottoms you throw away? Yup. Those bad cauliflowers with mold on them? Yup. Broccolis that were so bad you had to cut off most of the head (florets)???? YUP!!! I nearly gagged. After that, we just kept quiet and moved on.

They should be CLOSED DOWN. One star? Cos I can't give them NEGATIVE STARS! Good thing I didn't get sick, otherwise I would sue them. Only tourists eat there. Yes, the old lady, young lady and old guy IS NICE BUT DON'T TREAT PAYING CUSTOMERS LIKE BEGGARS. 

Even I buy fresh meals for beggars, not toss them some leftover food.
author: Jennifer K.

description:
I disregarded the bad Yelp reviews for this place and gave it a shot. I have to say it was pretty dang good for what you're paying. $5.99 for all you can eat which includes fried rice and noodles. Sui mais we're pretty good, probably because I got them fresh. The egg rolls could use a little more heat. The fried rice had no flavor, but not to worry because there was plenty of soy sauce, chili sauce, vinegar and white pepper available. 

The customer service was awesome. They are  genuinely nice people. Very lovely.

The place could use a little sprouting up though.
author: Alisa J.

description:
Dim Sum, Pastry and a variety of other food and beverage items in one stop? Nice!

I like it whether it is for eat in or to go, either way you know you have something to eat and drink when you are hungry and thirsty at the same time.

The Malay Cakes are really delicious, they come in a package of three. This item can be consumed for breakfast or a snack.
author: Bennett W.

description:
Be aware of the businesses you are supporting.

This restaurant accused of forcing employees to work 11-hour days, six days a week for less than $4 an hour


http://www.sfgate.com/crime/article/SF-restaurant-pays-back-wages-fines-4273029.php
author: Tom F.

description:
Whenever my family arranges a trip to SF China town, we usually order some dim sum to go. The location offers a $5.99 all-you-can-eat buffet where you pay at the front and they supply you with a styrofoam plate, plastic fork, and styrofoam bowl. 

The food itself is not quite sanitary judging from the actual cooking tools that they utilized to serve the food. It is decent since it is cheap and affordable but Dick Lee's Dim sum doesn't literally taste like DICK. There are probably better places in Chinatown to munch on affordable dim sum. 

If you are not a customer, you must pay a $1 fee to utilize the bathroom. The bathroom walls were stained and saturated by old feces and urine. I did my business as quick as I could to prevent myself from suffocating from the foul smell.
author: Christine L.

description: NASTY!  Sorry but this was the worst food experience ever. where to start?  My picture I will post here should be enough, not one but two dead bugs swimming in hot sauce. All items were room temp, Egg rolls were soggy and inside stuff was unrecognizable, Curry was all potato-no meat, all vegies were mushy and looked faded,  BBQ pork was mostly fat, Dim sum was older than the Rolling stones. It was difficult to find anything edible.  The City of SF should shut this place down. It was my 1st time eating in Chinatown now I think I have been psychologically damaged by this experience and doubt I will be back.
author: Phillip G.

description:
WOW....I wondered if this place would have reviews. It would rate -1 if Yelp allowed it.
