Just  read the other warnings on this page. How inhumane!! Now I don't feel bad writing the review below for my meal 3 years ago.
_ _ _ 

"Dick Lee's $5.95 All You Can Eat Dim Sum" -a coupon tourist trap.

Why try anything named Dick Lee's? 

3 years ago, my mom made me...such a steal she thought. We HAD to try it out...right? 

Why, mom, why???? I was so disgusted I had to drag my mom out of there because I couldn't stand it and had to quickly cleanse my pallet or I would start gagging. She was a trooper and didn't want to waste food, but our meal could have been detrimental to our health!

We walked in and I knew it was going to be bad when I looked around and saw paper plates and  non-asian people sitting there. No offense, but I'm not sure if non-asian people really understand what good dim sum should taste like. I took a bite of everything and kept finding bones and had to spit it out. There should be no bones in anything I ate!! Which begs me to ask...what are those bones I'm eating?

I turn around and see a huge mound of meat just smack dab on the counter  only a few feet away from the food on the counter. The workers were molding it and pounding it, and the place just screamed "DIRTY. RUN. Throw up or you'll be poisoned." That was the tipping point. I took my mom and promised her an expensive meal to make up for that goo we ate.  A little dramatic? Maybe, maybe not. The memory will stick with me forever.
author: Julie T.

description: It's a shame I don't know the names of the dishes I had but I will upload a picture of my plate.  One friend didn't care for anything while the rest of us ate till we were stuffed.  All you can eat for $5.99 and well worth it.  Small, quaint and friendly.
author: MyShawn C.

description: If negative stars were possible... I'd give this place minus 5! I had to go and eat somewhere else after I paid for the all you can eat ... Even for free it's not worth it. The worst food I've had easily in the last decade! This is my first review ever! So compelled by the awful food to write this,,,  I'm not talkin so so or ok for the value.... I'm saying my dog would turn it down... Whoah! The food standards of this are so far below.... Not even recognizable shrimp bits in the shrimp dumplings! One more bite of anything from this place would have made me hurl... I walked out... Couldn't even say a word or something to this cretin who would serve this stuff!  On my way out... Saw a sign that said no money back after you've tasted the food. Nuff said!!
author: Suzi C.

description: Owners are very nice. There is all you can eat dim sum for 5.99. The food is also very good for a great price. The duck and their house special deep fried noodles are bomb!! Too bad I live in oc
author: Ian L.

description:
Went to Dick Lee's at 11:30 on a Sunday morning.  Should have known the food was not up to par when we only saw one customer.  The establishment is advertised as an all you can eat dim sum and BBQ buffet for $6.99 (tea is an extra $.50 per person).  Also that they had 50 items.  Counted everything including the cookies and came up with a total of 25.  
There was no BBQ items, the har gow (shrimp dumplings) did not have a single shrimp, the pork ribs, the tofu, and the curried chicken were all swimming in gravy.  Lots of fishing to get any substance.  No egg custard tarts either so I can't comment on them.  The egg rolls were hot and crispy but the filling seemed to be a mush of vegetables.  
We are definitely not going back to Dick Lee.
author: el h.

description: Had all you can eat dim sim. The best egg rolls I have ever had. Dick was very friendly and kept offering us more food and putting food on our plates to make sure we were full. Bathroom had a lot to be desired thou. Would come back for sure!
author: Tash S.

description: Hesitant to enter from the outside but was pleasantly surprised. Ordered one steamed pork bun and one barbecue bun. Given two of each. Owner was very apologetic that the barbecue bun would be ten minutes' wait. Wonderful blend of locals and tourists. Owner was wonderful--very personable.
author: Lauren H.

description:
GAH the dimsum here.......frozen dimsum that you can buy from TJs or Ranch 99 tastes better!

The only pros are that its cheap and the girl who works there is super nice...

Everything tastes like it was made as cheaply as possible. I took a bite of almost everything and could not bring myself to finish any of the food here. 

Out of all my friends, I probably ate the least. Their dimsum is mostly cheap pork that has a lot of fat. Their egg tart tasted like its been in the warmer forever so it was mushy. Their chowfun noodles had no taste because they were all stuck together. :( They definitely need to improve their food. I don't see myself coming here again and I wouldn't recommend this place either.
author: Jeannie L.

description: This place a scam! $5.99 all you can eat dim sum gives you no napkins, no water, shrimp dumping with no shrimp, buns that are bought at the supermarket frozen. There were only a few limited choices, and they all tasted disgusting. Not only that, we waited forever for fried rice that we just walked out and with our stomachs not even filled. Even a cup of water is extra, as it will cost you an extra $1.50 per person. The shu mai tasted fishy, for sure not fresh, likely several days old. Avoid this place at ALL COSTS. Don't be lured in by the cheap price! Plus the guy overcharged us. I wish I could give zero stars.
author: S C.

description: Really good dim sum for 6 bucks -- all you can eat. The steam pork and red bean were very good and fresh. However, I would not go at night or right before they are closing as the dim sum has been sitting for a while.  I also got pork dim sum - very good flavor.  Finally, got the sesame seed ball - very large and good flavor. I'm def going back for more during the morning / mid day!
author: Louisa P.

description:
There is a sexy robot voice that enchants tourists inside with her calming English ways and a promise of all you can eat dim sum. Sail onwards sailor, take heed and don't be lured in by the siren call. 

Pros:
 The girl who helped me was such a sweetheart. Normally the service in Chinatown is no frills, "HowFastCanIGetThroughYouAndOnToTheNextCostumer" with none of those western  pleasantries. 

Cons: 
Usually sesame balls are chewy (like a soft gummy bear) with a silky paste on the inside. I bit into one of theirs and the outside crumbled away leaving what looked like a dried elk turd. I can't even imagine the age it must have been for the properties of matter to change like that.

Bottom line:
Saying that Dick Lee tastes dick-ly is an insult to penises everywhere. Price as an excuse for terrible food? Bu shi(t)! Take a walk down Stockton there's dim sum places on every block that serve it fresh, tasty, and they're cheaper to boot.
author: Zoe L.

description:
I've been longing for a place to get some good dim sum ever since jade villa in Oakland closed down. I've been away from good dim sum for so long that I actually decided to try this place.

BIG MISTAKE

I was in SF trying to decide where to get some dim sum. I heard the advertisement for this place, turned the corner and was greeted by a long line so I assumed the food must be good...thought to myself "well this looks promising.  Long line plus cheap food equals win for me!" 

Well there was a lot of food. Just not a lot of good food. EVERYTHING WAS DISGUSTING! The Siu Mai was absolutely horrible. So was everything in those warming trays. I was so disappointed. Furthermore, I didn't feel too good after them meal. 

In short: might be cheap but its not worth the dining experience. Go eat somewhere else. I'm never coming back.
author: John B.

description: I came here 2 summers ago.   The food was not very good although cheap.   Don't go in their bathroom.   It's very dirty ie feces on the ground.
author: Bofa S.

description:
I was in SF Chinatown wanting to get some egg tarts. I knew Golden Gate Bakery was really known for its egg tarts, so me and a friend waited in line for 15 minutes without the line moving at all. Since time in SF is precious for an out of town tourist, I couldn't waste any more time. 

As I headed back to my car, we passed Dick Lee Pastry Shop so I ordered 8 egg tarts (80 cents each) and some white sugar rice cake. As soon as I finished ordering the egg tarts and saw the waitress turn around, I regretted my decision. The egg tarts were crumbling and falling apart. And the egg part was bright yellow instead of that nice pale yellow. 

The rice cake (bai tang gao) was pretty good though. We don't find those in Atlanta very often, so it was nice to be able snack on some. 

Overall, it was not some place I'd recommend tourists to go for good food in SF. BUT, the prices are very reasonable, so if you're short on a budget and don't care about quality, come to Dick Lee!

[17 of 100]
author: Joy D.

description: Stopped in to experience some dim sum in Chinatown. Very interesting, I won't comment on the quality of the food since I have nothing to compare it too, but we had a great time and I would recommend going for the experience
author: Keagan V.

description:
Do not eat here!!!

Flavorless food.....and I'm about as non-picky with food as it gets. The dumplings, although full of meat, were bland, and their rice congee was basically water with some rice grains. I got really mad getting suckered into the cheap price with the "All you can eat:" sign, but I guess I should have known better about too good to be true prices in San Francisco. 

Bathroom usage is charged $1 unless you're a customer. I can make better dim sum at home myself. The owner did say "I'm sorry" in Cantonese upon seeing our disappointed faces as we left the premises.....I really didn;t know how to respond.

If I could take away the one star, I would, It doesn't help that most of the customers, from what we could see, are tourists.........leaving them a bad impression of Chinatown. Urghhh,,,,

Please do yourselves a favor and check out other restaurants. Please.
author: Andrew W.

description:
My friend Tadashi Y. and I went in for the infamously cheap $5.99 all-you-can-eat buffet. The first indication that we were in for a bit of a adventure was the disposable plates and cups that we were handed.  We gwai-los definitely didn't  rate as important enough for the melamine plates that we saw in the hands of other patrons. The food itself was passable but definitely far from gourmet. You absolutely get what you pay for.

The Good:
I recommend the diced chicken and tofu with salted fish. It was by far the best thing I had from the whole buffet.  The pork siu mai, sweet and sour meatballs, char siu (BBQ pork) weren't half bad as well.

The Bad :
Mush (or the lack thereof)  seemed to a big factor in the quality food here. Its works in some things but not in others. The egg custard tart was a good example of if not working. the crust was okay but the custard part was mushy and didn't have the chew of a good custard tart. The Taro Wrapped Sticky Rice also had a lot of the mush factor.  It looked good enough  as I unwrapped it but the rice kernels were all one big ball of mush as I took a bite. One bite and no bueno.

The Weird:
Their chicken "leg" was weird. It was actually a bunch of different ground meats that were formed onto a "leg bone", coated in an unnaturally yellow batter and deep fried. There was actually a sign that warned me of the amalgam of meats inside but I misread it and assumed it was referring to something else on the line.  The mix was actually okay once I knew what it was but that first bite expecting chicken and getting something completely different threw me for a loop.

All in all, most of what I ate was satisfactory and the low price was definitely a good thing. I think if I had to pay much more for this buffet I would have definitely rated it lower.
author: Sherman B.

description:
I was always curious of this place when I was young. After all, it seemed like great food for a great price. 

I went to Chinatown with my friends a couple of weeks ago. After a long day of walking, we were ready to wind down, relax, and have some food. So I decided to choose Dick's as a rest stop.

The horror...the horror...

Filthy seats. It is like they didn't even try to clean up after you. Well that's because they don't. The food looked and smelled like low quality dump you'd find in the dumpster of a third world country. Unable to stomach the idea of eating the buffet, I chose a smaller 3 dollar combo meal. I got a spoon of fried rice one SMALL pork shumai, a TINY beef dumpling, and a cookie. The rice had no flavor. The meat products had the suspicious taste of rot. The cookie was alright.

Observations I saw:

*I went to the bathroom they had. You can say it had "chitty maintance". If the food didn't make you throw up, the restroom will.

*Three girls who needed to go to the bathroom walked in. After realizing they had to make a purchase, they saw the food options. In disgust, they left.

*My friends weren't brave like me. They didn't order anything.

*Lots of flies.  

I would not recommend this place to anyone. I don't even know how this place passed health inspections. If there was any redeeming feature of this restaurant, the girl at the cashier was a sweetheart. So I give Dick Lee Pastry Shop a 1 out of 5 Holy Yelp Stars (Since I can't go any lower).

If you feel like taking an adventure in Chinatown, choose another restaurant. There are many great options out there. Chowing on Dick is as low as you can go.
author: Eric F.

description: We've been buying our dimsum here for years. I must admit, quality has gone down. Our most recent purchase on NY's eve was the turning point not to ever go back.
author: Marie C.

description:
Places to actually sit: Check
Friendly staff: Check
Wonderful food: It was better than OK
Price: $5.99!!!

Wow!  For the money, worth it without a doubt.  No after meal issues, either.  The iced coffee (extra $2) was also good.

Awasome variety.  Good flavor.  Some items not as hot as could be but $5.99!
author: Ben B.

description:
5.99 all you can eat, not even worth 1.99!!! My little niece eats food and she doesn't even eat that. 
Food taste like salt, can I have a bag of instant noodle instead?
Not fresh
author: Iron Chef V.

description:
This place is cheep but the only thing it think is good is the egg custards

Minus 1 star for the annoying advertisement which has bad grammar but all you can eat buffet for 5.99 where else can you get a better deal
author: Peter C.

description:
Folks, the Chinese name of this place in Cantonese is pronounced

"Duc Lei Ga Feh"

The first two characters loosely translate to "acquiring luck" (or good fortune). The last two characters are "coffee". 

Has anyone reviewed their coffee here?

Uhm they also sell cakes, pastries, and mooncakes here.

But the question that sometimes keeps me up at night is 

Why do old skool SF Chine$e American$ love this place so much?

A big reason mu$t be the $6 all you can eat low brow and low tech SIM DUM mini buffet! A$IAN AMERICAN CHEAPNE$$ FROM THE GOLD RUSH DAYZ! 

Let's face it, Duc Lei's Dick won't sell dick at Koi Palace or Yank $ing. There's a reason why they keep the Sim Dum inside.

More power to you if you prefer portions over refinement. This type of place easily caters to non discriminating Sim Dummers who forego quality for cheap $hit.

Update: Lolia "the Original Froyo Girl" S just told me that Dick Lee sometimes uses low quality meat in their congee, occassionally to the point of rotten. 

Downgraded to one $tar. That Dick, what a dick. But not as dicky as the mashed up cardboard and pork fat steamed pork buns drummed up by a reporter in China with a street food vendor  to sell more news.
author: Ken K.

description:
Dick Lee is a great deal, It's an all you can eat Dim Sum spot that I checked out when my girlfriend and I were starving and kind of broke. But the dumplings, wontons, tofu and eggplant were pretty good. However, I do not recommend the desserts they were dry and tasteless with exception of the cookies. I think what I enjoyed most was the Jasmine Tea...it was the most flavorful and sweat tea I had tried even though it had no sugar. Lastly, the owner and employees where very friendly and kind, also the Sesame balls are pretty good treat on your way out to explore China Town some more. 

Cheers
author: Miguel M.

description:
Two stars because I'm feeling generous and the meal wasn't so bad that I wanted to throw up.  

But the other Yelpers have pretty much summed it up: DON'T COME HERE.

It was Memorial Day, and I was walking around Chinatown with food buddy and fellow Yelper Joseph N., hoping to find some good dim sum.  I don't know the go-to Chinatown dim sum spots at all, since this isn't my hood, and I don't find myself here often.  And I don't think Yelp is especially helpful when it comes to hole-in-the-wall dim sum eats and treats because I feel like the community in the CT ain't gonna be Yelpin', amirite? iamrite.

Anyway, we're walking around, randomly, and we see a ginormous All-You-Can-Eat-Dim Sum for $5.99 sign.  For some reason, we were especially attracted to the sign, like innocent, naive little flies drawn to. . .poo.  Sorry for that very unflattering description, but the food really was shitty.  

Because for $5.99 you get some dim sum staples like shrimp and pork dumplings, BBQ pork buns, and then a buffet line of greasy Panda Express-ish foods.  The shrimp dumplings were passable, but the pork dumplings were just plain weird and not good.  Everything else was really meh and sometimes eew.  Not tasty.

But I mean, it wasn't like I wanted to throw up after the meal; at least it was edible, which is why this didn't get one star.  

Also, for those of you who think $5.99 is cheap, it really isn't THAT cheap.  Let me break it down for you.  A typical dim sum meal, shared among a group of 4 or 5 should cost you around $30 - $40.  That's about 6-9 steamers of food (Been eating this stuff since I was like 3 years old. I know my dim sum = don't question the math.), so if you split among a group that size, you should reasonably be paying about $7-$10 per person.  Let's say you order a little less food so that everyone is about 75% full instead of full-on-beach-yourself-like-a-whale-full.  If we're at that end of the spectrum, then you see that $5.99 is really not that cheap at all.

So, yes.  Do yourself a favor and go somewhere, ANYWHERE else for dim sum.  Sorry I can't give recommendations for Chinatown.  I think there's this sit-down, banquet style place called New Asia for dim sum, and they were decent the last time I went, but I don't remember much else about it.  

But definitely hit me up if you want recommendations in the Richmond District.  Heh, maybe you shouldn't just avoid this place, maybe just avoid Chinatown altogether.  Save yourself the headache.
author: Vivian C.

description:
This place is hilarious!  It just brings back memories from eating at restaurants in Hong Kong or mainland China.  Seriously, people shouldn't be complaining about the cleanliness of the place.  It's CHINATOWN.  Most of the people there are straight off the boat from China and with that, bring along the customs/practices of running a restaurant in China.  And in China, it's about getting you the food, eat, then get out.  It's a business, get over it.

Now on to the food.  I was really hoping that since it was majorly based off China restaurants, the quality of the food would be the same.  I was with my girl to pick up some food togo to bring back to her family, some siu mai(pork/shrimp dumpling), ha gao(shrimp dumpling), jin doie(sesame balls), and bai tang gao(sweet rice cake).  They had everything already in steamers except for the ha gao, definitely a must have dim sum staple.  They told us to wait 20 mins since we had ordered a lot of them , kind of strange since I know it doesn't really take that long to steam them. It ended up being roughly 25-30 mins but I was glad they were fresh.  We both tried one and well, it was.....fishy. Not good.  I remember trying them before but being better.... All the other dim sum pieces were decent but not at all the best dim sum I've ever had.

We didn't get to try the AYCE $5.99 buffet but we watched everyone get in line for it.  They actually give styrofoam plates, styrofoam cups, and plastic forks....hahahah. SO ASIAN! And if you're not a customer, it's $1 to use the bathroom so don't even try because the cashiers have hawk eyes.  

I really wish the food was better but it just didn't cut it.  Maybe even a 1.5.
author: Justin L.

description:
Many people are calling me a "baller" or "pimp!" That is not true. I'm just an "assed-out yelper" struggling to get by these days. It's just three more days before pay-day and I can't wait. 

Being broke, I've decided to eat some Dim Sum at the newest Richard (Dick) Lee bakery. Formerly located top of the hill for a long time, the newest location have added an "all you can eat" Dim Sum buffet and restaurant for $5.99. Food from Shiu-mai, Shrimp dumpling, Fried Rice, Chow Mein, Black bean pork spare-ribs and yes, the custard tarts just to name a few.   The food may not be the greatest and healthiest, but really affordable.

The drink costs $1.50 for a can of Shasta. My goodness, you're better off getting a drink from the outside or drink the complimentary tea or coffee. 

Like most bakeries in Chinatown, Cash only! (And I barely have cash too).
author: Matt G.

description: I was looking for a dim sum place that was open past seven that serves seafood, veg, and sweet options since I do not eat meat.  The all you can eat sign lured me in and the owner kept me for about an hour.  He was cheerful and super accommodating - made separate dim sum for me so I could have my share of seafood/meatless options!  I loved the taro and lotus bao.  There was plenty of food put in front of me -including noodles and rice - and I left satisfied.  Glad I stumbled upon this place!
author: Dana K.

description:
I've been there a few times, and the previous reviews are generally accurate.

But, I generally go there just for the dim sum.  With Dim Sum going for $3 for 3 pieces in the restaurant and my primarily eating sui mai and haw gow, it was a deal at $4.99.

I probably ate 30+ pieces, some FREE hot tea and nibbled at the 15+ items on the steam tray.

It's actually a deal if you just go for the dim sum.

If you are looking for good quality hot food items and outstanding dim sum, this is not the place for you.

AND - if you were ever that their previous store, you would understand what an improvement this location is.

The other location was TOO Chinese authentic with fly strips, seeing baby mice run on the ground, and an old man rewashing the plastic utensils that were thrown in the trash.  I kid you not!

If you have the sensitive tummy of a 10-year old girl, don't go.

If you have a cast iron stomach, you'll love this place for the price!

If you're somewhere in the middle - flip a coin!
author: Siliconvalley G.

description:
I ate here...it wasn't bad.
But it was not good either.  The recording is so obnoxious and loud.  
Their dim sum...way too much pork fat in everything.  

Price = dirt cheap...and for a reason.  
Ick.

Just writing this...is making me want to regurgitate my meal here from a few weeks ago.
author: Fannie S.

description:
Ive read some of these reviews, and they are a load of crap. This place has some amazing food and very friendly staff. They also have good tea. The egg custard is absolutely delicious. I just moved here to sf from florida, and ate here on thanksgiving. I have been coming back 1-3 times a week ever since. 

All these negative reviews are hearsay, or are coming from those who live in some fantasy world in the hills. There are no mice, the place is very clean in my opinion. I have always received clean plates and flatware. I have never been disappointed. I have taken friends, and they were absolutely amazed by this place as well. I would recommend this place to ANYONE.

ALL IN ALL, i highly recommend this place. 5 STARS!!! all the way
author: Charles M.

description: Dick Lee is a whole in a wall place, its pretty much street food in a small cramped building. The selection of dim sum is large and cheap. As with all street foods you to have a iron stomach , its more of a local thing. If you've traveled to third world countries youll see that this style eating is the norm. I usually grab some to eat while i am there and a few boxes to bring home to share with friends.
author: John M.

description: Big mistake stopping in here... don't be fooled by the allure all a 5.99 all you can eat offer... you can't eat any of it, because it is awful. Dirty plates, dirty cups.
author: Brett C.

description:
I ended up here because my roommate said that this is where she always goes with her family for dim sum. It's definitely different from the places I've gone to get some dim sum. 

I thought that the price was alright considering that it's buffet style, but there isn't much. As for the dim sum, I had no idea what I was eating and it didn't seem like there was a variety.
author: Lauren Y.

description:
Just read the rest of the reviews, it's all been said already. Friendly service, atrocious food. I thought I might as well try their 6.50 all you can eat dim sum. Nothing was edible. Everything tasted as if it had been sitting out for a week. Luke warm, cold, dry, soggy. 

Move on. Sorry, Dick.
author: Felix L.

description:
My adventurous friends were lured in by the friendly staff and the $5.99 all you can eat dim sum buffet. It's a bad selection that includes many foods that aren't traditionally on a dim sum menu. Good dim sum is one of those things that you just need to know better. Sure it's edible, but the only folks who would think this food is good must 1) have never had good dim sum (save their souls!), or 2) have a liking for leathery mystery food. 

Don't do it. 
End of story.
author: Sally T.

description:
Dick Lee Pastry probably offers the best value all you can eat buffet in the past when their quality was much better than it was on a recent visit.  But you are better off buying what you wish to go as their prices are low, you get a better value buying what you want to go.  But of course you may go for the buffet, you will only get full before you get as good a  value.  People would line up to buy their food products, the place was busy.  Take a seat at a table and circle the items on the menu and it will be brought to you, that was before when I visited them when they were located at 777 Jackson St.

Now, you pay upfront, select whatever you see available and appeals to you.  Unfortunately, the quality has gone down, way down.  Now when I visited, I see rows of empty tables with only a few customers.  Hot tea is included, they charge for bottled water, restrooms for customers only, else it's USD 1 charge to use it.  You won't go away hungry if you're willing to eat their food.  It's not very good, and not satisfying.  I'd rather pay more for better quality food else where.
author: George L.

description:
Don't be fooled by the $5.99 dim sum offer you seriously will get what you pay for. The selection of true Dim Sum foods is extremely low and the quality of all the food offered is pretty appalling to say the least. To be honest, I didn't expect much from a place this cheap but it was way below the standards of the competition surrounding them. The egg custard, which in my opinion defines any dim sum place, was lacking the sweet smooth flavor in the custard as well as the flaky buttery crust which in this case tasted like frozen pie crust. 

By paying just a little more at other places (basically 2 dollars), you'll be way more satisfied in the quality of the food as well as the passion that goes into a true dim sum cafe in the heart of chinatown. Go for the place across the street from here, the one with the green roof, you'll be glad you did.
author: Evan S.

description:
I've been going to Dick Lee for quick, cheap dim sum for years.  The new location seems to cater more to tourists, so I feel I've become displaced and have moved on in search of greener pastures ... well, You's on Stockton, actually: http://www.yelp.com/biz/yous-dim-sum-san-francisco-2.

If you guys watch The Office, this place would be like Pizza by Alfredo (all-you-can-eat of pretty good pizza, not the medium amount of good pizza that everyone wanted).  

You guys ever hear of the "5-second Rule?"  Well, in my family, Dick Lee's is famous for the "Negative-2-second Rule" - once the food has touched the table (or anything else), it's already two seconds too late!!  This place is dirty!  And the new location is much cleaner than the old one was...
author: Chris Y.

description:
*note: this review is just for egg tarts*

Golden Gate Bakery was closed because they went on vacation.  

Con sarnit.

Dick Lee's was the closest dim sum-to go place I could find on a traffic-jammed Sunday morning.  I had 5 minutes to run out of the car, get some egg tarts, and get back in the car, in hopes that the car didn't cross thru the intersection again to make another circle.  You know how CT parking is...

So I ran into Dick Lee's, asked for 3 egg tarts and paid all within 2 minutes.  Hooray for making it back into the car.

Sadly, the egg tarts were disappointing.  They didn't taste awful but you could tell not as much quality and care went into making them.  Their shell was kinda soggy and the custard wasn't firm... they kind of tasted like... BBQ pork. 

Oh well, What can I expect for $1.50? :P

P.S. t'ain't too clean in here either...
author: Elizabeth T.

description: ugh, I hate to say something nasty.  The lady at the counter is so nice.  But this time around, I had an awful taste in my mouth for a day. TONS of better options for dim sum in town. Gross.
author: Abigail J. M. M.

description:
If there's one thing I learned after eating here is "never trust any restaurant that advertises dimsum buffet with cheap graphics in a tour guide!"  The only thing I take comfort in is that I wasn't the person that chose the restaurant.  My friends visiting from out of town actually chose the restaurant out of a tour guide and the "$5.99 dimsum buffet" ad caught their attention, so we ended up there.  We were driving in and being that the place was in Chinatown, parking and traffic was going to be a hassle to deal with.

At first glance the place looked really ghetto, but it had a really nice bright yellow canopy.  When you walk in, it's a completely different story.  I remember sizing the place up as I was slowly walking cautiously in as my friend was making the arrangements to eat in.  There were no decorations on the wall and the floor looked like the kind you'd hose down at the end of the day at a meat market.  I guess the best way to describe my impression of the place is "picture yourself in the worst neighborhood of your hometown and how soon you'd want to get out of there" and you pretty much get an idea of how I felt about this place.

After paying the money we made our way to the available food.  It isn't all the time I see the eating utensils and napkins in troughs in front of you, but I tried not to notice.   The restroom at the back of the restaurant was your typical hole in the wall, but I had to laugh when the sign in front of the door says 'Restrooms are for Paying Customers Only,' while there is a small token/coin device at the lock on the door.  I guess if you didn't want to buy the food and use the bathroom, you could just pay a quarter or something and still be considered a "paying customer."

As far as the dining experience goes, if you can get past the annoying advertisement that is played at full volume complete with the music accompanying Chinese Lion Dancing followed by the "5.99 All You Can Eat Per Person" announcement playing repeatedly off of a small computer monitor at the front of the restaurant, you're good.  We were there for at least an hour, so for us it was a huge test of patience while trying to eat and have a conversation.

As for the food, it seemed like it had been out for a while.  The only things that I thought was edible were probably the steamed siu mai and dumplings.  Everything else seemed hard or cold when I got to it.  And then there was the egg custard.  Is there supposed to be an oil layer on top of it?  The crust was flaky and I could taste an egg, but I wouldn't call it tasty.  Oh, and as for the hot beverages, they only had tea and hot water, so if you had a penchant for burning your tongue off, then this place is perfect for you.

Final thought, if you just want the novelty of the sights and sounds of this place, go for it.  Just don't stick around for very long and eat there.
author: Ray N.

description:
If you're having trouble picking out which place to eat at while in downtown sf, here's one place you can knock out. Yes, it's cheap ($5.99), but. If you're frugal, do yourself a favor and pay 2 or 3 more dollars elsewhere to get better dim sum.

The selection isn't that great, and some foods are excluded from the buffet section. At first, you may get excited by that huge tray of egg tarts (dan ta), it looks pretty good. Don't take too many, it tastes more like stale bread and eggs. Good egg tarts are sweet, flaky, and the egg part is somewhat creamy. But here at dick lee's, the egg part is chunky.

The sesame balls aren't very good either. Good ones are slightly crunchy with soft filling. Here, it's opposite. And it's extremely greasy as well, like everything else they serve. 

I am very sure you've had better $5.99 food. It's not that hard to fill yourself up at this place with their fatty foods. Basically, look elsewhere for better eats.

I don't think I'd eat here next time I visit bay area.
author: Alfred F.

description:
All you can eat dim sum buffet $6!!  The atmosphere just screams "ghetto hong kong".  The food isn't the best but it's not terrible.  It's a little more oily than what I'm used to but you get what you pay for.  They have the basics, shrimp dumpings, shu mai, spare ribs, beef dumplings, soups, noodles.  

So I've decided to socialize and ask (in chinese), "why the low prices?"  They basically said economy is bad and they needed to be more competitive.  

My advice?  Don't get more than 2 plates or just dab some of the food on napkins to absorb some of the oil.  As I said, for the price, the food isn't half bad.
author: Geoffrey N.

description:
Let's face it. I was lost in Chinatown and I was living off of the "Bay Area Guide" magazine. My family was hungry because we've been going around and around. Of course, the "All You Can Eat Dim Sum for 5.99" was appetizing. Once you got in, it was sort of a different story. It looked like a fast food buffet sort of thing. It looked pretty old, and the food seemed okay.

         Well, the food was pretty bad. The dim sum was mediocre to pretty bad. I saw what looked like "har kau" but inside, it was definitely not shrimp, it was like a corn paste. The shui mai tasted okay, but was decorated messy. Seriously, the red paste thing on top of the shui mai made it not delectable. There is also the chow mein and the other buffet food. 

         If you eat here, its more like a you get what you pay. I'm not going there the next time I visit SF, and seriously, I heard that they underpay their workers to afford the cheap price. No wonder the food seemed so sloppy.

         I hate being the person who deface someone, especially since I knew it was very very cheap, but don't expect much when you eat here. 

-Happy Eatings !
author: Nell A.

description:
Like I have said earlier, I look at my misguided tour of the side of Chinatown the tourists don't venture into during my first SF excursion as an unexpected adventure in retrospect. That said, while I tried to make the best out of it due to not having very much money, the food I had here wasn't very enjoyable. 

(Yes, I would have written a review a long time ago, but I couldn't remember the name of this place for the life of me. I'm visiting SF again soon and while doing trip planning I just happened to stumble upon it).

Mushy egg rolls, weird dumplings, oily chow mein and boney chicken. The fries were the best part unfortunately.

There was also a pigeon walking around the floor, and they insist that you throw your leftovers into a separate wastebasket so the food can be recycled back into the trays. Yuck. And don't get me started on that false advertising. Sign outside says 50 items, inside there's barely even 20. 

While doing research, just to make sure this was the same place, I just so happened to stumble upon the news story which claimed this: Workers were paid 3.80 an hour, worked 10-14 hour shifts and weren't paid for the 6th day they worked (which wasn't overtime, but a requirement). No wonder the food was subpar and the employees looked so miserable. 

I feel bad about eating here now. :(
author: Philippe C.

description:
I can't speak for the restaurant as I've never eaten there, but food stand they run right outside of it after closing is pretty much awesome.

$1 for a lotus leaf wrap ("jung"), $1 for a huge slab of turnip cake? 

Come on ppl...that is, by the definition, "Woohoo! As good as it gets!  

Being a city-yuppie away from the traditional food of my chinese parents, it's nice to know I have somewhere to go to for taro and turnip cake.
author: Kendra W.

description:
The horror....I give them an extra star for not making me sick even though I was sure I'd be doubled up over a bowl later that day. 

I think the hubby was a-skeered of Chinatown and wanted to get my dim sum discovery over with quickly. We stopped in with the promise of all you can eat for about $6, which is a bit pricey considering what you can get in neighboring places for that price. 

We should have checked it out and walked the line before shelling out the monies. The horror....

The interior is like a cafeteria. They give you a little "kit" of disposable dinnerware and off you go. The hubband noticed that they liked to position the tongs as inconveniently as possible for the high-value meat items. The aesthetic went well with their continuous loop over the loudspeaker announcing what they offer in the buffet. 

Shu mai was more of a solid pork meatball with drying skin. There was a slightly tainted flavor that I couldn't tell was rot or a bad recipe. There were no shrimp dumplings I could see (dammit!) but I did pick out a couple sad-looking scallop (?) dumplings. The skins were shiny and looked old. The scallop or whatever seafood was in there had the same tainted flavor as the pork so maybe it was just an odd chinese herb they used. Nevertheless, I spit out the second dumpling.

There was an abundance of pork meatball-like items. The two pork rib-meat thingys tasted about the same. I didn't see any shrimp anywhere. The bbq pork steamed buns had a pretty tasty filling but the bun was over-steamed making it too moist. 

The wontons in the wonton soup were edible though the broth was basically water and the pork filling the same as all the other pork meatballs. 

The egg custard wasn't too bad. The pastry was flaky and a little crunchy. The custard was very eggy and not really sweet at all (are they supposed to be? I'm not incredibly familiar). It was edible. possibly enjoyable, and not repulsive. 

I was bit afraid of the hot line. The bbq chicken was ok though I was horrified to see them taking the over-cooked bits and casually tossing it into an adjacent dish (wtf?). There were mysterious fried things and cheap chinese fare that wouldn't pass the quality test of the local grocery store's deli counter.

I'm back in Seattle now and the first place we're eating is the city's cheapest, best dim sum place so I can learn to love dim sum again. This place killed it.
author: Bye Y.

description:
My experience here was not good at all. Seeing that advertisement in the SF Tour Guide caught my eye. Like everyone said, it is an All You Can Eat Buffet & Dim Sum for 5.99+tax. That's pretty cheap especially for dimsum. Usually dim sum is 3 for $1.50. 

The food was no where near decent. I got oretty disgusted after the ha gao. There was this weird smell. After my first bite of the ha gao, I kind of wanted to throw up. There was this bun I tried with chicken and cabbages and the taste totally threw me off. I love Chinese buns and I'm not a type of person to waste food. 

I decided to come back for a ha gao again, just because I guess, and next thing you know, I see hair and these small, black stuff on it. That just concluded my lunch there for the rest of my life. I'm sorry to say that I will not come back here for their food.

The SF tour guide should have suggested a much better Chinese restaurant for tourists! That's the only way a trip to San Francisco can be worthwhile!
author: Chau T.

description:
If you want your food to taste like cock and balls, come here.*  
Just giving you the heads up, in case you wanna go down anyway.

You don't have to blow your load here.
At about $6, you get the all-you-can-eat dim sum.

For some, they just want some protein in their stomach.

            -3

"Like" is used as a metaphor in this figure of speech for bad tasting food.

**

Update at the end of the day:  I got one girl who liked the taste
and one guy who wanted her phone #.  Wow, I should be a matchmaker.
author: CT L.

description:
2 syllables: 

NAS - TY

Strictly Dick Lee?? Not in this case.
author: Jen A.

description:
An urban hike through Chinatown today got my tummy a rumbling, and what popped up? 5.99 all-you-can-eat dim sum! A woman's voice came over the loud speaker luring us in from the street with a sexy robot purr: "You can have pork buns, egg drop soup, pork dumplings and barbeque...." The place was packed with Chinese and locals alike, and we were sold!

We headed over to the buffet, and loaded up on all of the goodies, but it was obvious once we sat down and took our first bite that somewhere we had made a misstep. You remember that episode of Dirty Jobs where Mike Rowe takes on the back alleys of Chinatown with the garbage man? If you can imagine actually eating those leftovers thrown out the back doors and onto the street, you'll get a sense of what it was like to dine at Dick Lee's.

Gulp. I get a little nauseous even writing about it. Excuse me while I run for the alka seltzer.
author: Nicole G.

description:
Dick Lee's all you can eat dim sum for $5.99.

I knew what to expect when I heard that. But it's ok, I need some crappy food sometimes (really?). Here's how it went:

1. Walk in
2. Pay $13 in cash for two people
3. Receive a paper plate, plastic fork and spoon, and a plastic bowl
4. Fill my plate with cheap, lukewarm food
5. Sit down and eat my cheap, now only semi-warm food
6. Walk to the dessert (maybe it will fare better than the food?)
7. See the very brown bananas
8. Leave
author: Christine L.

description:
I can' t believe the rating of this place. The blaring sounds might turn a lot of people away. I walked in because I always look inside and not outside. 

For 5.99 + tax ($6.30), I did a takeout, which is rare for all-you-can-eat places. I have: all sorts of pork, shrimp dumplings, tofu and mushroom, bay leave wrapped sticky rice, egg custards, buns (egg yolk), beef ribs, rice rolls, sweet black sesame rolls, glutinous with red beans. 

All the dim sum were still in the bamboo steamer and were hot. I did not really take any chow fan or other noodles because they're too filling. 

The quality is actually not bad at all, not top notch but look, for that kind of price you usually could get a bowl of soup from SF Soup company with bread and it would not even be filling and the quality would be just okay.
author: T L.

description:
They moved down the street by the way.

Ew ew ew ew ew ew ew.
My mom brought dim sum home.
I found a piece of hair in my black sesame roll... 
My mom is wondering why I didn't finish my lunch.

There's a lot more better dim sum places in Chinatown, just because they have a new looking location, doesn't mean their food is any better than it was before. Food here isn't very sanitary... I've heard other horror stories from friends too. Trust me, I'd know because my mom has been buying dim sum here for years.

----
BTW, I find their 5.99 dim sum advertisement that runs 24/7 on that little TV screen SUPER annoying.
author: Natalie G.

description: Yeah, if your planning on dining at a nice place forget about Dick lee..it's a no frills dim sum spot, speaking Cantonese helps...
author: jonathan h.

description: Dick Lee one of the nastiest Chinese food places in San Francisco. Definitely not fresh. The food tastes like it's been sitting out for three days. I also read that the employer doesn't pay ot to workers no wonder they serve shitty food. What a waste of $6.50 for food that shouldn't be over $2
author: Lawrence F.

description:
Note: If they catch you throwing away food you are charged a FEE. You gotta be ninja-like about throwing away your leftover bits.

You think I'm joking - oh no. These are asian people. It's a serious offense at this place to the point where they start charging you if you waste.

We were walking around chinatown and originally intended to eat at you's dim sum(but for the lack of an english menu and not a lot of food available to choose from by physically pointing we decided to come back another time try a new place, haha.) 

it's a relatively cheap price, especially for the unlimited amounts of egg custard(what can I say, I was hungry and the egg custard had good consistecy) the fried rice was ok. *pause* I mean, it tasted like fried rice. Wontons were so-so, as was the selection of dimsum available. The broth in the wonton soup, however was a bit too watered-down. 

The hot and sour soup was decent(with an extra sour kick), and the steamed buns were pretty good. 

It was pretty busy when we went, and bustling with chatter - but it's chinatown. 

They take debit, it's great. I may not come back for dimsum in the immediate future, but stopping by to get some dessert it a definite posibility.
author: Susan K.

description:
Man it's hard to say anything good about this place, but for comical reasons I just can't give it one star.  You have to hear the looped recording that they play all day long to really understand.  As you sit there in the restaurant, you keep hearing the recording over and over again, and it just gets better.

Some of the food was tolerable, some of it was decent, but most of it was just bad.  You can fill up for $6 or less per person at Dol Ho, or pretty much any other Chinatown dim sum joint.
author: Joseph N.

description:
The $5.99 all you can eat Dim Sum sign both intrigued and frightened me... but I threw caution to the wind and went for it. This place was packed and pretty disorderly so after scanning the buffet I was ushered to the cashier and paid my $6.50 with tax and was handed a plate, a bowl and a cup. 

I meakishly walked up to the buffet and lightly loaded up my plate then took a seat. I took a few small bites of the different things on my plate sipped my soup then got up threw everything in the trash and left still very hungry.

Heed my warning and stay away or go and learn the hard way.
author: Thel D.

description:
I used to like this place because it's the only place I've found so far that sells lotus seed buns. About $1.50 for 6 buns. Then I realized, that's the only reason I like them. When a old Chinese granny shakes her head at them (that happened last time), you know they're bad. More a pale beige than the dark brown they should be. Sigh, let me know where some good lotus seed buns are in SF. 

I also tried their all you can eat. Ugh. The dim sum is fatty and the color is off. The noodles wouldn't be too bad except for the amount of grease on it. It's not even good greasy food, just bad greasy. Egg tarts had a thick layer of pastry and little flavor in the egg part. Etc. I thought the food was ok at first. The more I thought about it, the less I like this place.  I tried to rationalize that you get what you pay for and it's not bad for $5.99. Then I realized: I'm in Chinatown! $5.99 is too much to spend on bad food in this part of town.  

Their tea was decent.  The recording of their dim sum offerings still amuses me. You can hear it a block away.
author: Yan E.

description: I'm pretty easy to please when I'm hungry and when I see "All you can eat dim sum" hand written on a sign outside of the restaurant, my heart starts to pitter patter.  There are so many wonderful places to eat in China Town, but it seems like whenever I come here I have to stop in.  I've had the buffet three times and take out in the pink rope tied boxes several other times.  The dim sum is better than average considering the price; I especially enjoy the pork with shrimp shumai, beef shomai and shrimp dumplings.  This is one of the few places in San Francisco where you can get 4 days worth of food for under 30 bucks.  No joke, I've done it as a starving college student.  This place has become somewhat of a novelty to my family, it's comforting to eat food from here...kind of like opening an original can of SPAM.
author: Lemmor P.

description: Do not enter!  They are very persuasive in getting you in the door with their $5.99 dim sum/Chinese buffet.  We fell for it and regretted it!  Food was almost not edible. I'm pretty open to dirty, hole in a wall places but the food here was pretty bad. It was like I tasted Chinese 5 spice on everything!  Only a couple of the dishes were ok, but the rest either were horrid in taste or tasteless.  The next hour I was waiting for the worst, but thankfully i was fine.  Note to self.........ask around, in China Town.
author: David M.

description: This review is for the egg tart and black sesame rolls. Yummy, I haven't had these in months. Vivian served me in the front as there was a high demand for Chinese tamales (Canto: zhong, Mandarin: zhongzi). There are 4 different kinds to choose from and they are pretty huge! Anyway, the black sesame rolls are $.60/each but 3 for $1.50. The egg tarts are above average in taste and texture. For some reason I like the liquid on top of my egg tarts which is always a good sign (personal preference). This is an actual local business (well, chinatown is practically all mom-and-pop shops) so you are doing yourself a socially-responsible favor by patronizing here. Cleanliness is ok and there is no wait.
author: Dominic T.

description:
I was drawn in by their cheap price and the speaker that blares a constant looping of their offerings out onto the street.  Looking back on it now, these things should have been warning signals.  

I don't have very high standards for food, but, wow, this was pretty damn gross.  To make money off of $6, they fill the buffet up with starches, like noodles and rice, and sickly-looking mystery meat.  Really questionable stuff.  After you're done eating, you don't want to be wondering to yourself, "Am I going to die from eating this?"  Just really gross.
author: Jon N.

description: Like lots of other people have said this place wasn't great but it also wasn't terrible. For the price I feel like I honestly got my money's worth. The hot and sour soup was delicious but the fried veggie rolls were mushy and cold. My friends all said pork buns and dumplings were good and I really liked the semi-weird mixed vegetables. Overall I would go back again just for the experience, the hot tea and the desserts.
author: Kally R.

description:
If there's one thing I love its a CHEAP BUFFET!!!

Mwahahahahahahaaa! 

One w/ dim sum too?! Heyyy, dim sum's really expensive!

- Yea the food's pretty nasty (all things considered).

- Yea the inside's pretty rank (again all things considered). 

- Yea the blaring obnoxious announcer voice & TWO 90s hit songs they keep playing over & over again gets annoying. 

- - - - - - - - - - -

That said, like others admitted in their reviews: I DIDN'T GET SICK eating here! 

Honestly, I thought the food was fine (no where near 5 star cuisine, but it tasted appetizing at least) with the exception of the soups (yuck!). 

The shrimp su-mai was yummy! I ate a bunch of those. The Chinese food on the buffet line was decent (lots of vegetarian options which was nice). 

* THE PLACE COULD BE A LOT CLEANER, THOUGH!!! * 

.... 
........
.... 

All things considered, when I decide I want to spend $6 for shrimp su-mai and all-you-can-eat Chinese junk food...

... this place is A-OK in my book.
author: Kai S.

description:
The horror...the absolute horror. It's the day after and I'm still having the "dick lee's" (my new term for diarrhea, ex. - I ate something bad and I had the "dick lee's all night long). 

Okay, my buddy tells me there's this place in China town that serves cheap Dim Sum. My inner Homer Simpson takes over and I figure I can handle anything, so I decide to take him up on his challenge. 

Upon arriving, I hear a loud speaker of a Chinese woman speaking English with a heavy accent. Reminds me of "Tokyo Rose" telling the G.I.'s to put down their weapons and stop fighting. But, in this case, she was telling us to put down our common sense and eat there. 

I walk in and I see no Chinese, except the workers - Strike 1. I go through the line of mixed...ahem...food...and I see some things that do look familiar. 

I go for the chicken, then I reach for what I think is something made with shrimp, followed by what appears to be extremely hard pieces of pork in sweet and sour sauce. 

I take my first bite and it reminds me of my childhood years when I used to eat dirt. Well, to be quite honest, dirt tasted better. Because of my inner Homer Simpson, I had to try everything at least once, so next was the sweet and sour pork...I think. 

I had sat there for about 15 minutes hoping my pork would absorb some of the sweet and sour sauce, but to my amazement, it was resistant - like water on the back of a duck. But, when I took a bite into it, it was still hard and crunchy. I mean, real hard - Strike 2. 

I sat there and managed to eat the food because I didn't want to have to pay another $5.99, which would just add insult to injury. 

I can honestly say, that the only good food there was the almond cookie. But, I think my comment here deserves an Astrix because, I saw a pink box where they were storing the almond cookies. Therefore, truth be known, they bought the cookies from some other place - Strike 3.

If you read this and you still go, I warned you. As to those people who rated it 3, 4 or even 5 stars...they were paid to do that survey and they took their well-earned money and ate some where else. 

To my friend, who shall remain nameless, all I can say is, "Friends don't let friends eat bad dim-sum!" 

Now, I have to go. I feel the "dick lee's" coming back...
author: Robert G.

description:
This is a hole in the wall mom and pop shop. I always like to support these kinds of places. I've been here many times when I'm in San Francisco. I always make a stop here for lunch or dinner when I am in Chinatown. Today, I had dinner here and I enjoyed it. The worker/cashier is friendly and there are many authentic chinese home cooked hot items to choose from along with dim sum selections. Dim sum includes pork dumplings, egg tart, pork shu mai, shrimp dumplings, a variety of buns(bean or BBQ pork), congee(rice porridge, 4 different kinds of soups(hot sour, wonton, stewed beef or pork soup egg flower soups), fried chicken, roasted chicken, chow mein, fried rice, bok choy, tofu with meat sauce, BBQ pork, lotus dish, mixed vegetable with meat dish, and many more. Selection is great! For the price of an All-You-Can-Eat of $5.99 per person, it is a great price and the best in town! Especially if you are on a tight budget. The food is pretty decent  for me and for the price, you can't beat that. I would definetely come back again not having such high expectations like some of these yelpers have. I also have to say that somedays the quality is better than other days. Today, I found that the dim some quality was better than the last time I was here for lunch time. If they are really busy, then the food is more fresh as they try to replenish it more often. Hot tea used to come with the meal but today, they said they would charge an additional .50 cents. I've been here for years and this was the first on that. It should come with the meal like it always had. Also, the place is not all that clean(hole in the wall). You get a paper plate and a bowl. You can order a la carte and get real dishes. I always prefer the AYCE because I like selection and there is no waiting for the food, especially if you are in a rush to eat and go. Like I said, don't expect much. Food is decent and for the price, you can't beat that,especially on a budget.

Update 8/2016 No more hot food entrees for all you can eat. All you can eat is limited to some dim sum Only. Terrible! Lunch is $5.99 which is a good deal so it lures tourists in by the cheap price. You get what you pay for. I heard him say dinner is $7.99. Selection is very small- All you can eat is dim sum only. Before, they had soups and hot entrees and it used to be self serve. Now, you have to order the dim sum and it's not self serve. They were suppose to bring it out to us and they didn't for about 20 minutes. So I asked the owner where my food was. After 20 minutes, he told me to get the dim sum myself. He should have told me that earlier so I don't waste all my time for nothing! Dim sum wasn't good and it took forever to get the food. Bbq pork buns tasted bad-it seemed old and sitting in the steamer too long. Shu- Mai's  tasted better since it was fresher and big. I gave two stars because they didn't charge for my kids and the owner seemed nice. I kept asking him where my food was because we sat there for about 20 minutes. Very disorganized.Bring back the old way with more hot food selections besides dim sum and make it self serve like you did in the past. I won't be coming back unless they had it like before. What a disappointment. The good news is that I never gotten sick here so far which is surprising because some of the Shu Mai meat is pink. Another positive feedback is that the food is a good deal for $5.99 but it was not very good. Like I said. You get what you pay for. I feel bad to writing this review because the owner seemed nice and friendly to customers and originally I gave them 5 stars. I'm surprised that when I came here Aug 2016, there were so many changes for the worse.
author: Paula L.

description: Absolutely disgusting. The ingredients they used at this place was so cheap to the point the food was inedible. It has a great setup to trap tourists.
author: Wesley C.

description: Stay far away from this place if you care about your health.  Tried the $5.99 all you can eat dim sum after looking at what was available.  Nothing at all tasted like the dim sum dishes they looked like.  We ate one bite of a steamed dumpling with sweet filling and the filling was rock hard and brownish color instead of the yellow it was supposed to be.  I tried almost everything available on the all-you-can-eat menu in an attempt to find something enjoyable but was disgusted at every single thing!
author: James M.

description: When this place relocated down the block on Jackson Street, they changed their business scheme to being an all-you-can-eat dim sum place.  One afternoon, being in the area, I gave it a try.  It definitely was not good.  None of the items appealed to me.  In the end, I did not even eat very much considering it's buffet style.  Even the soup tasted rather bland.  Most likely I will not go back for the buffet.  At most I might pick up a pastry from here.
author: H K.

description: This little take-out dim sum shop has been on Chinatown's Jackson Street for ages. Unfortunately, they have not taken their culinary skills into the new millenium even though they've been in business for decades.  I stopped by whilest in the area and wanted a little snack...I ordered a few items that looked like they've been in the steamer for a few days and I asked if they were rubbery.  The counter lady said no and they were tasty.  Knowing otherwise, yet a little hungry, I paid for my order.  All the items I had were tasteless and the won ton skins on the Hai Gow were rubbery.  Even if it's only $6.00, all you can eat, why would anyone subject themselves to eating such crap?  Never again.  I think next time I should just settle for a bag of chips instead.
author: Gina L.

description:
On a city block saturated with at least 4 other shops of its type, this one clearly has its strengths:  moon cake.  Both yellow bean and mixed nut varieties are excellent.  Give them a go.

Their dim sum is all right, measured by har gow, siu mi, pork buns (both steamed and baked), but nothing to write home about.

That looping A/V presentation they have at the entrance is a chuckle-treat.  Limit your dose, or you might be hearing it in your sleep.
author: Alfonso E.

description:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1Stihw9mdmw

it sure is cheap.
author: Patrick A.

description: Sadly I meant to go to Yong Kee, not this place, but I ended up liking it too. I liked the quality of the Chinese food and that it was all you can eat. But I was disappointed with the lack of dim sum food. That was why I had come!
author: Jamie M.

description:
This pastry shop has moved to 716 Jackson St, half a block from where they used to be.  But you don't miss anything if you can't find them, cause the food quality is BAD!!!

For $5.99, you can have a all-you-can-eat dim sum buffet. This is equivalent to one single order of shrimp dumping at the Yang Sing restuarant!  So how do they keep their heads out of the water- simply lower the quality of the food and increase the work load of their workers.  You have been warned!

Still curious about what kind of dim sum they serve? Visit their website...

http://www.angelfire.com/80s/dickleepastry/DimSum.htm

You will get a kick out of it!
author: Helen L.

description: Um, yeah...you get what you pay for. Yuck! It's a day after went went, and one plus in their favor is that nobody has reported illness. Moldy mushrooms and gray "beef" should not be sold as "food." Don't be fooled by anything here; walk on by.
author: Catherine B.

description:
Dick Lee's was a staple for me when I was in college in San Francisco. When you're a starving student, you tend to find good cheap places.  I loved their dim sum but most of all...their sesame balls -- especially the red bean or the black bean ones; yellow was ok, but it was a bit too sweet.  Their sesame balls were always warm and so mouthwatering good.  They were extremely cheap as well.  How I loved Dick Lee's in my early twenties.

Fast forward *cough* almost 20 years later...I was wandering around Chinatown, cranky, pissy and cursing at myself for even thinking of venturing out into the city. I had taken Bart in and it was packed. I let my feet do the walking because I wanted to visit old stomping grounds and see if they were as wonderful as I remembered them.

I found myself in front of Dick Lee's. It was STILL $5.99 for a dim sum buffet. Nothing's changed.  It's still crowded because they decided to add in another table. The $5.99 dim sum buffet included canned sodas -- all you can drink to boot.

Their sesame balls and all their other dim sum was just as yummy as I remembered. It's pretty authentic and not for the faint hearted.

My husband was with me and started to get squeamish. Please.  We've been to scarier places when we lived in Scotland.

He was pleasantly surprised when he ordered his dim sum.  I'm not sure if we will go back...snotty Euro-peon that he is.  :p

Their decor leaves a lot to be desired. It's not really decor as much as it just boxes. Dick Lee's always reminded me of a house that someone decided (on a whim) to make into a restaurant because someone told the owners that they make good food. They put in tables, but it was never really pulled together. When you visit, you'll see what I mean.

If you're looking to drive to get here...good luck.  Street parking is awful.  If you can't parallel park, please -- don't drive, you will give the City dwellers even more things to get worked up over. There is a parking structure a few blocks away, but do you really want to pay those outrageous prices?
author: Carina M.

description: People with money shouldn't come here, but I did.  It fill me up,  I assume that people that complain about this place never been to other parts of the world.  Some places are worst,  but I never been to Southern Hemisphere.   I use my metal powers to block out the recording of the voice and focus on the Hong Kong concert or Hong Kong Music videos on TV. Try not to sit in the front of this place that where the  recording is coming from.
author: John F.

description:
Dick Lee's is the kind of place that you can't really rate.  It's off the charts when it comes to random ambiance (They used to store their empty produce boxes in the dining area but then they built a wall so you can't see as many boxes any more.   I miss those days.  Then they added a shelf of used toys, the kind you get in Mc Donald's happy meals, that they sell for $3 to 5 each - makes no sense).  

I recommend the huge slices of sponge cake and all the dim sum is pretty good (and cheap, cheap, cheap).  They use weird left over meat in the congee but I'll keep eating it any way, because it goes with dim sum.  

$5 gets you the all you can eat deal, which they announce on loudspeakers to passerbys.  Random again.  Gotta love it.
author: Lolia S.

description: you get what you pay for. i see them selling old toys next to their food.
author: Allie Y.

description:
Don't go there, it's just a tourist trap with sub par food, you get paper plates, the food isn't even warm, I would rather die then eating their food. Luckily I was just their with friends and i wasn't too hungry, otherwise I would have demanded a refund.

DO NOT GO.
author: Eric T.

description: wow heard they were using slave labor!!! dont eat here
author: brian w.

description: Several of my co-workers and I recently visited Dick Lee for the promise of $5.99 all-you-can-eat dim sum.  The food was as horrifying as the atmosphere.  What's worse is that Dick Lee has the nerve to charge a $3 food-wasting fee if you toss the stale, cold, remanufactured, jelly balls they pass off as dim sum because you didn't like them.  And trust me, you won't.
author: Ryan B.

description: At first I thought, wow, $5.99 for all-you-can-eat dim sum? It's probably gonna suck but it's still a steal! Then I actually tried it and thought, well, I guess you get what you pay for. Then I kept eating and it just got sickening. Even though I like cheap, I'd rather pay more for better stuff.
author: Jonas T.

description: The worst meal of my life....literally...it's been 24hours since and I am still feeling the aftermath...6.4 earthquake in my belly....or is it Mount Everest about to rupture....this place is GODawful.....but the best part is the signage on each table "waste of food is an additional $5.99 charge"--are you kidding me---we barely took one bite from everything offered and shoved it to the side. i didn't feel guilty wasting food thinking of starving people in the world b/c this food is not fit for human/animal/organism/parasite/cockroach consumption...disgusting....
author: Trish t.

description: I grew up with this place! I love it! My mom used to work here about may be 20 years ago. I remember when I used to be sick, my grandma would always take me here to eat the beef rice rolls. I love the rice rolls here, they are not oily as the other places in Chinatown. I wished this place would get cleaner and may be look a little more better.
author: Janet Z.

description: We came here on a Wednesday at 5:50pm and it was closed without any signs on the door. What's up Dick? Your website says 6:30pm.
author: Dan X.

description: I used to come here just to get some dim sum to go when I would visit SF but I feel the quality has gone down quite a bit over the years.  I used to come a lot probably almost 20 years ago!  The place looks kinda janky now and I would be skeptical of getting their all you can eat lunch.  Chinatown dim sum is pretty cheap and I don't know how much you would be able to eat anyways.  The thing I liked most from this place was they have this steamed rice ball thing that I really like and would use to always order.  The last few times I ordered it, they really skimped on the meat and it's basically just a giant rice ball without much flavor anymore and I've been going there less and less.  Before it used to be better.
author: Wilson C.

description: Yeah definitely would not go back. I should have watched Anthony Bourdain or done some yelping for a great dim sum place, but hey it wasn't horrible. Many mystery meats which are always welcome, and hot tea and hot water, OK...Hey it kind of felt what I imagine Hong Kong might be like a little, cafeteria like seating, crowded, bad lighting, floor covered with liquid that might make a fat tourist pull a Buster Keaton, London Bridge is falling down. Yeah it was an experience, and look ma! no diarrhea!
author: Nathan W.

description: we were walking around Chinatown, got hungry it was late in the afternoon wanted some dim sum,  passed by and hear the mystery woman talking.  The price 5.99 was right but there a catch, wasnt much of a dim sum selection, food tasted kinda old. I guess when they hand you a paper plate and a plastic fork something isnt right.  Well we didnt get sick .
author: D L.

description: I would never miss this one if ever I visit again San Francisco. Good food+ good cheap price? It doesn't get better than that. And I enjoyed the hospitality of the friendly staff!
author: Pau D.

description: You get what you pay for.  We made a trip to Dick Lee last week and was drawn by the $5.99 ALL-YOU-CAN-EAT dim sum deal.  The dim sum did not taste good at all.  Nothing tasted like its suppose to.  The only thing that was decent was the few desserts and egg tart that they had.  But at $6 a person, you can fill yourself up and have left overs at another nearby dim sum place that makes better food.  One thing good though is that it has a lot of tables comparing to other tiny Chinatown stores.
author: j t.

description: Great deal for some cheap dim sum!  I bought 24 postickers for $3, and some 15 pork siu mi (forgive my spelling!) for about $6 total.  The sui mi was plump and full of ground pork goodness.  It is difficult to tell what they have, as there is not much of a menu.  You would have to know what you want, and order up.  It's not stellar, but the price cannot be beat.
author: Michael M.

description: I strongly urge everyone not to eat here. The "all you can eat" should say "all you are able to stomach," which really isn't much. All of the meat dumplings we had were undercooked and still pink inside. The sweet and sour chicken was filled with ground up bones. Everything generally tasted the same and was rather gross. The wonton soup and egg drop soup both smelled and tasted nasty. After taking a bite of everything I decided to stick with the rice just to have eaten something for lunch, and my stomach still felt bad afterwards.
author: Kristina S.

description:
I myself also like Yong Kee. There food is alot better than Dick Lee. If I have to choose, I would recommend Yong Kee. They have really good steamed buns. as for Dick Lee, for $5.99 all you can eat dim sum...I really wonder what they put in it. Grease and FATS. You can get cheap dim sum elsewhere and not just Dick Lee. 

I've been eating at Yong Kee for many years. Everytime I'm in Chinatown, I would go in for steamed buns, fun gor, rice noodles, ...

This site mention other good foods in chinatown which I like too. You can try them. As for Hing Lung, it use to be better but still not too bad. There deep fried donuts still really good.

http://www.fooding411.com/2008/04/trip-to-san-francisco-chinatown-golden.html

Yong Kee
732 Jackson St
San Francisco, CA 94133
 (415) 986-3759
author: i r.

description: I love this place. Inspection score 40 something =D. I will go back and buy more dim sum at 5PM =D
author: James L.

description: A serious tourist trap if I have ever seen one. Fell right into it. False advertisement was the key to luring people in. Food was not fresh at all and was the worst dim sum I have tasted. Would definitely not recommend this to ANYONE! oh... and there is a sign posted that says "there is a $6 charge for wasting food".... Seriously? Would give 0 stars if possible.
author: Jameson B.

description:
seriously, Dick Lee? 

the restaurant isnt very clean, and they have a stupid video outside that annoys the heck out of me, and they can never get my order right. also, why am i always the only one in the restaurant who doesnt speak chinese.

three starts for the cheap cheap dimsum and really good (crunchy, tender) egg custards and mooncake.
author: Lynne O.

description: Yelp should allow me to put no or negative stars for this establishment. I have never tasted food that disgusting and terrifying in my life before. I was lured into this place by the big sign outside "Eat and Eat again". No tax and no tips. For just $5.99, you will get the experience of your lifetime. Apart from the grease, the food was just stale. The cabbage tastes like plastic sheets and you just can't bite through it. The spring rolls had wiry cellophane noodles and when you bite on it only the outermost layer fell off. The fried egg was hard as kitchen tiles. The wontons were boiled for hours until they became furry. FURRY wontons gave me FURY. I was really worried about food poisoning but since I have paid $5.99 I decided to tough it out. I doubt even bacteria wants to grow on dessicated food. Wait a moment... Did I just call these "FOOD"? The server actually urged me to eat more and I nearly burst out laughing. I have to be fair, the tea actually tasted like tea.
author: Liz T.
